descricao: The Jesuit priest José de Anchieta had highlighted performance in the catechization of Brazilian indigenous. Conscious of the strong impression that music can produce to the aborigens, he used European songs to the catechism. The Jesuits also taught the indigenous to play some instruments.

item.texto: He was received in Coimbra to attend University. The choice of Portugal and not Spain is a point not yet sufficiently clarified. In Coimbra the Canarino "heard Dialetics and part of Philosophy (...) along with the Letters". The dedication to the studies, literary talent and religious fervor distinguished him in the University.
Embarks to Brazil in the fleet of ships of the second Governor General Duarte da Costa and he will meet the Priest Manoel da Nóbrega arriving in São Vicente.
The jesuits founded the city of São Paulo on the day of conversion of the apostle, and "so we dedicate our home to him", explains Anchieta.
A few months after arrive in Brazil, Anchieta learns the local language Tupi and writes a grammar that was adopted in manuscript copies in Piratininga from 1555, and 1560 in Bahia.

In the mission to negotiate with Tamoios against the Portuguese, Anchieta became hostage to indians. This year he wrote a poem in honor to Virgin Mary on the beach sand in Iperoigue (Ubatuba, São Paulo). Villa-Lobos used part of this poem in his 10th Symphony, composed in 1952 to celebrate the 4th Centenary of São Paulo.
The fleet comanded by Estácio de Sá arrives in Rio de Janeiro. Attending his call, Nobrega and Anchieta leave São Vicente 19 March.

Anchieta leaves Rio de Janeiro and goes to Bahia with João de Andrade to receive holy orders. In Espíriito Santo, he visited the Casa da Companhia and some Indians villages.
	In Bahia, he was received by Luiz da Grã and ordained by bishop Pedro Leitão.
Anchieta returns to Rio de Janeiro at the Mem de Sá's expedition. The day after he arrives, February 20, Estacio de Sá was murdered by Tamoios in Ibiriguaçumirim.
He was elected rector of the Rio de Janeiro high school.

In Coimbra, Portugal, is published the "A Arte de Gramática da Língua mais usada na costa do Brasil", by Anchieta. According Agostinho Ribeiro, “the book would do much to improve the instruction of catechumens and the rise of Christianity, and also to plant more gentle our Faith in that regions”.

descricao: Antônio José da Silva, o judeu ("the Jew"), is considered the most important dramatist from the first half of the 18th century. His works include operas Vida de D. Quixote de la Mancha; Esopaida, or Vida de Esopo; Os Encantos de Medeia; Anfitrião, Júpiter, e Alcmena; Labirinto de Creta; Guerras de Alecrim e Manjerona; Variedades de Protheo e Precipício de Faetonte.

item.titulo: De mim já se não lembra

item.texto: António José was six years old when his entire family was forced to leave Rio de Janeiro and return to Portugal following the escalation of the Inquisition in the colony.

During this year, he was imprisoned in Coimbra along with his brothers for two months. He was subjected to various forms of torture, which left him incapable of signing the terms of recantation of the Jewish faith.

His first opera, Vida de D. Quixote de la Mancha, premiered in Lisbon's Bairro Alto in 1733. This play estabilished him as a playwright who was developing a style that would breathe new life into the theatrical performances of that era.

item.titulo: Guerras do Alecrim e da Manjerona

item.texto: Composes the play Guerras do Alecrim e da Manjerona.

obras.titulo: Guerras do Alecrim e da Manjerona

item.texto: The Holy Office chose not to spare Antônio José's life due to his satires, although this was not explicity mentioned during his Inquisition procedure. He was executed in the public square that year.

descricao: One of the most important musicians from Recife during colonial period, Luís is the only author of Pernambuco music samples from 18th century. He studied in Portugal and nowadays we know that he produced many pieces, religious and secular works, but most are lost.

item.texto: Luís goes to Portugal to study with Henrique da Silva Esteves Negrão, organist of Lisbon Cathedral. There he worked composing, copying scores, teaching and playing cello at Real Chapel.
Back to Pernambuco, he writes his essay A arte de solfejar, whose manuscript is nowadays in Lisbon National Library. In this essay Luís included his 24 Lições de Solfejo.
He composes Divertimentos harmônicos: 1 - Beata Virgo; 2 - Benedicta Tu In Mulieribus; 3 - Quae Est Ista; 4 - Eficieris Gravida; 5 - Oh! Pulchra es.

obras.titulo: Lições de solfejo I, II e III
Lições de solfejo IV e V
Lições de solfejo VI e VII
Lições de solfejo VIII e IX
Lições de solfejo X e XI
Lições de solfejo XIII e XIV
Lições de solfejo XV e XVI

item.texto: His comedy in three acts Amor mal correspondido debuts at Opera's House, in Recife, and remains being performed until 1783.
Becomes a chapel master of São Pedro dos Clérigos Church, holding office until 1789.

He publishes a dictionary for children, Dicionario pueril para uso dos meninos ou dos que principiam o abc e a soletrar, and writes two music textbooks: Arte pequena para se aprender música and Arte grande de solfejar.

descricao: Besides being a composer, he was an Army Ensign and also a calligrapher. As a musician, he served in Tiradentes, São João d'El Rey and Congonhas do Campo. In some works of his vast repertoire, Manuel used poems of the missionary Ângelo de Siqueira (1708-1776). Handwritten sources of his works can currently be found in the main archives of Minas Gerais.

Composer, poet and guitar player. Writer of satires, he moved to Portugal to avoid problems with some important people. Caldas Barbosa was one of the most popular Arcadian poets and his poems was turned into modinhas.

item.texto: After completing his studies at the Jesuit Scholl in Rio de Janeiro, he serves the army at the colony of Sacramento until 1762.
Abandons the military career and embarks to Portugal to begin his studies in Coimbra.
With other relevant authors, such as Bocage and Curvo Semedo, he inaugurates the movement known as Lisboa's Nova Arcadia and adopts the pen name Lereno Selinuntino.

item.titulo: Os teus olhos e os meus olhos

item.texto: Composes Os teus olhos nos meus olhos.

obras.titulo: Os teus olhos e os meus olhos

item.texto: Viola de Lereno is published, containing lyrics of his modinhas and of popular songs played at the time. The second volume of Viola de Lereno was published after his death in 1826.

nome: José Joaquim Emerico Lobo de Mesquita
nome_completo: Mesquita, José Joaquim Emerico Lobo de
descricao: He is considered by many as one of the most prominent composers of the "Escola Mineira" (Mineira School). Copies of his works were preserved in almost all music archives in Minas Gerais and oter states, which gives us an idea of his importance during his time. All of his works are essentially vocals (solo or choir), religious and many of them with an orchestral accompaniment.

item.texto: There are few records of the life and work of Lobo de Mesquita. His more creative phase correlates with his activities in Serro and Diamantina cities. The autographs from his works provide proof of production between 1778and 1803. All his works consist of religious music, almost in Latin. Among them is the Missa para a quarta feira de cinzas (Mass for Ash Wednesday).

obras.titulo: Missa para a quarta feira de cinzas

item.titulo: Missa para a quarta feira de cinzas

item.texto: Diamantina city, at that time called Arraial do Tijuco, witnessed an intense musical activity during the second half of the 18th century. At that time, Lobo de Mesquita performed distinct activities in the city such as teacher, composer and organist.
Entered into the Ordem Terceira do Carmo, in Arraial do Tijuco, Minas Gerais, staying in this fraternity until mid 1795.
Possibly the biological son of José Lobo de Mesquita, a Portuguese citizen, and his slave Joaquina Emerenciana, Lobo de Mesquita married during this year with Tomásia Onofre do Lírio.

Lobo de Mesquita moved to Rio de Janeiro, the capital of the Colony, where he signed a contract with the Ordem Terceira do Carmo to work as an organist. He played for the mass in this fraternity's church until his death.
One of his Ofícios de defuntos (Mass of the Dead) was performed at Vila de Caeté, Minas Gerais, in memory of the empress Leopoldina, who died the previous year.

descricao: Marcos did a brilliant career in Europe, having operas staged not only in Lisbon, but in many Italian cities and other important courts, like Paris and Saint Petersburg. He was the preferred compositor of Dom João, unwilling in coming to Brazil, what just happened in 1811. Some of his operas were staged in the Real Teatro São João, in Rio de Janeiro. He never returned to Europe, dying here in 1830.

item.titulo: Sucede, Marília bela & Já, já me vai Marília

item.texto: At the age of 14, composes a Miserere, for 4 voices and organ, which figured in the catalog of Marcos' compositions. It was also notable his learing during the chant and organ studies.
He was admitted in the Irmandade de Santa Cecília as a singer and organist of the Patriarcal.
He was named master of the Salitre Theatre. By this time acquires great fame as a composer. The song he wrote for the Salitre pleases well becoming popular.
Composes an oratory in Italian, by Luís Torriani, dedicated to Senhora da Conceição.
Some of the great maestro's compositions are published in the newspaper Jornal de Modinhas and stay on vogue at the concert halls.

Marcos arrives in Rio de Janeiro, being received by the Regent Prince and the court with the greatest considerations and esteems. His first compositions in Brazil are the Grande Missa, composed for 4 voices and orchestra, and Matinas de Natal, for Christmas festivities.
By order of the Prince Dom João, composes works designated to the slaves of the Santa Cruz Farm, among them A Saloia Enamorada, with Domingos Caldas Barbosa's poem.
It was performed his allegorical work O Juramento dos Numes, for the São João Theatre inauguration.
Composed the Missa de Réquiem for the Queen D. Maria I obsequies.

It was performed for the first time, at the São João Theatre, the Hino da Independência (the Brazilian Independence Hymn), composed by Marcos Portugal and also with Evaristo da Veiga's verses. That song was officially the Brazilian Hymn until 1824.

descricao: Marcos Coelho Neto is, curiously, name of both father and son. The father played horn, clarion and timpani and was a conductor. The son, as well as composer, was conductor, horn player, clarionist, trompeter and bugler. He practiced his musical activities in Vila Rica (nowadays Ouro Preto) in the County House of Representatives, at the Opera House and also in the First Militia Regiment. He has always worked beside his father.

item.texto: He becomes conductor of the Blessed Sacrament Brotherhood, where he remains for approximately ten years.
He is appointed conductor of the music for Desposorio's Infante Celebrations.

Joins the Venerável Ordem Terceira dos Mínimos de São Francisco de Paula, for mulattos, and the Irmandade de Santo Antônio, formed of white people, being an honorable exception to the racial prejudice of the time.

descricao: Considered the most important Brazilian composer of the beginning of the 19th century, he is known for a vast high-quality repertoire. With the arrival of Portuguese court in Brazil, in 1808, his talent amazes the king D. João VI so that he is later named Master of the Royal Chapel.

item.texto: Both his mother and aunt realize his early signs of musical talent and hire a composer from Minas Gerais, Salvador José de Almeida e Faria, to teach him music.
At 16 years-old, he composes his first piece of music: Tota Pulchra Es Maria.
At 17 years-old, he signs the foundation act of the Sisterhood of St. Cecilia as a music teacher.
Composes Ladainha de Nossa Senhora for four voices and organ.
Composes the hymns O Summe Redemptor Carmen and Pange Lingua.
He achieves notoriety in Rio de Janeiro for an instrumental composition: the Sinfonia Fúnebre.
Requests priesthood ordination, approved in 1792.
He reaches a time of high productivity, composing around 32 works, including two Miserere (1798).
Signs of copies of duets and trios by Maurício Nunes are founded in the inventory of Salvador José de Almeida e Faria.
He is named public music teacher and hosts free music classes at his own house.
He is named Chapel Master of Sé.
Joins the Sisterhood of Nossa Senhora do Rosário and São Benedito dos Homens Pretos, and composes another set of musical pieces.
Composes the motet Te Christe Solum Novimus.
Composes the Te Deum para as Matinas da Assunção (CPM 91) and the Missa em Si bemol (CPM 102).
Enriches his instrumental music repertoire by composing A Tempestade (cpm233) and Zemira (cpm231).

D. João promotes the Carmo Church to the cathegory of Royal Chapel and names José Maurício Nunes Garcia Master of the Royal Chapel, appointing him responsible for the music in commemorative and liturgical days.
Arrival of the Portuguese court in Rio de Janeiro. On the day after the disembarkation, a mass took place with José Maurício Nunes Garcia music, which highly impressed the Prince D. João.
Composes Missa de São Miguel Arcanjo and also Missa de São Pedro de Alcântara (CPM 105), this one dedicated to Prince D. João.

obras.titulo: Missa de São Pedro de Alcântara

item.titulo: Missa de São Pedro de Alcântara

item.texto: Composes the Te Deum in gratitude for the "pleasant trip" of the royal family.

obras.titulo: Magnificat das vésperas de São José

item.titulo: Missa pastoril para a noite de natal

item.texto: Starts to compose for the church Ordem Terceira do Carmo, located next to the Royal Chapel.

obras.titulo: Matinas da assumpção de N. Srª.

item.texto: Composes the Novena do Apóstolo São Pedro (CPM 66) and Bendito e Louvado Seja (CPM 12), for Real Fazenda.
Composes Matinas do Apóstolo São Pedro (cpm173), for the sisterhood of São Pedro dos Clérigos and another Bendito e Louvado Seja (cpm13), for Real Fazenda.
Conducts music in the mass that turned Brazil in United Kingdom, celebrated in the church of São Francisco de Paula, in Largo da Sé Velha.
Composes a Laudamus that resembles Rossini's music, whose operas were becoming famous in the theatres of Rio de Janeiro.
He writes the Compêndio de Música e Método para Pianoforte, one of the first music methods in Brazil.
From this crucial year, the only known work is Novena do Santíssimo Sacramento (CPM 75).
On behalf of the sisterhood of St. Cecilia, he is commissioned to write a mass, currently known as Missa de Santa Cecília (cpm113).
Declined the title Cavaleiro do Hábito de Cristo, for the sake of Apolinário José, the only one he recognized as his own son.
In the presence of his son and a slave, José Maurício dies whispering a hymn to Nossa Senhora.

descricao: He was a student of the great composer Joseph Haydn. During his stay in Rio de Janeiro (1816-1821), he was strongly impressed by the popular sounds such as lundu and modinha. He pioneered the use of Brazilian tunes in classical music.

item.texto: Neukomm begins studying in his hometown with the organist Weissauer and later with the composer Michael Haydn. He is appointed honorary organist of the Salzburg University's church where he studied philosophy and maths.

He moves to Vienna where he studies with the great composer, considered to be the Symphony's father, Joseph Haydn. Towards the end of his life, Haydn assigned to his favourite disciple - Neukomm - the task of orchestrate and adapt to piano several of his works.

He travels to Russia carrying with him a letter from Haydn addressed to Czarina Maria Fiodorovna who had been his student in Vienna while she was only the Great Duchess. Still in S. Petersburg he was appointed Chapel Master by the Czarina. He composed his first and only opera, Alexander am Indus, staged on the coronation day of Czar Alexander.

obras.titulo: Die neue Oper oder Der Schauspiel-Direktor
Zwei Schottische Lieder pour le Pianoforte
Scena composta per la Signa Hunnius

item.texto: He arrives by boat to Rio de Janeiro with the artistic French mission and falls in love with Brazil. Records of the time mention his profound admiration for father José Maurício Nunes Garcia (1767-1830), considered to be the greatest Brazilian composer of that time.

Neukomm writes his first classical work inspired in a Brazilian modinha by Joaquim Manoel da Câmara, L'Amoureux as well as O amor brazileiro, a piece for pianoforte influenced by a Brazilian lundu. He also writes Sonata - Allegro Ma Non.

obras.titulo: Marche à grande orchestre militaire - n.3
Elégie sur la mort de Sophie Gail

item.texto: Composes the work Duo for flute and pianoforte.

Collects and organizes about 20 modinhas authored by Joaquim Manoel da Câmara. This collection, printed in Paris on the same year, constitutes one of the first records of modinhas in history. This collection is also the sole testimony of Chamber art and an important document about the musical activity in Rio de Janeiro in the early 19th century.

descricao: He started out as a violinist and a composer in the Teatro de Guadalupe in Salvador. Later he transferred to Rio de Janeiro where he became the violinist in the Royal Chapel in 1819. Although he returned to Salvador in 1828 his works continued to be played in Rio. Many of his manuscripts from his vast musical production are still preserved in the Municipal Archive of Salvador.

item.texto: At 18, Damião joined the infantry starting his military career.

Although the date that Damião arrived in Rio de Janeiro is controversial amongst researchers, there are stories of him being present in Court already in 1808, including having travelled in the same ship as D. João from Salvador and that the musician had "the good fortune to be nominated to accompany the HM (...) practising the art of music in the sovereign presence"(...)

A dispatch by Vigário Capelar da Sé de Salvador in November, mentioned that D. João VI had organised Damião as the next Chapel-Master of Sé de Salvador, when the position became vacant. At the time the position was held by Alexandre Gonçalves da Fonseca (Father Alexandre) who had been Damião's teacher.
After spending nearly two decades in Rio de Janeiro, where he served the Royal Chapel as a violinist and composer, Damião returned to Salvador.

Although there is a scarcity of sources relating to Damião's activities during the last decades of his life, the almanacs of Bahia from 1855 and 1856 make reference to the musician as Chapel Master of Sé at this time, a position that he probably held at least for a few more years.

descricao: Composer of "modinhas", he sang accompanied by the guitar and probably didn't know musical notation. It was Sigismund Neukomm who wrote down and has harmonized 20 modinhas and published them in Paris on his return to Europe. If not for this, there would be no record of their works.

item.texto: There is a testimony of Freycinet, dating back to 1817 that says "Nothing seemed to me more astonishing than the rare talent on guitar of mulatto Joaquim Manoel. Under his fingers the instrument had an inexpressible charm that never more have I found among our most eminent European air guitarists".
It has been said that he lived in Rio de Janeiro at the time. It's possible that he studied music at the Conservatory of the jesuits.

One of the difficulties in the dating the modinhas of Joaquim Manoel is the fact they were originally recorded on paper with harmonization of the pianoforte by Sigismund Neukomm. Marcelo Fagerlande, in his paper "Joaquim Manoel improviser of Modinhas", highlights that the transcripts were made between 1819 and 1821, and were published years later by Neukomm in Paris.

descricao: He lived during first half of 19th century and there were very rare notes about his biography. He was considered the best tenor in Rio de Janeiro during the 1820's and is author of "Modinhas de bom gosto".

nome: João de Deus de Castro Lobo
nome_completo: Lobo, João de Deus de Castro
descricao: Considered the greatest name in religious music from Minas Gerais in the early 19th century. In this valuable work he incorporated the Classicism and Romanticism influenced by Italian opera, which distinguishes him from the composers of Minas Gerais of the 18th century. Among his works we can distinguish the Missa em Ré Menor, Matinas de Natal, Matinas do Espírito Santo, Missa e Credo a 8 Vozes e Orquestra and the Abertura em Ré Maior.

item.texto: His Abertura em Ré Maior, an orchestral work discovered by accident by the researcher Harry Crowl and written on the first half of the 19th century shows, according to this researcher, "a solid contrapontistic development, as well as a great dominion of the orchestration from its time".
He becomes an organist of the Third Order of the Church of São Francisco da Penitência, in Mariana.
Studies music at seminary Ribeirão do Carmo, actual city of Mariana, were he is ordained priest. He quickly becomes chapel master at the city's cathedral.
One recording is issued of the work Stabat Mater on the CD Música do Brasil Colonial: compositores mineiros, composed for choir, violins, violas, two flutes, two horns and bass.

descricao: Composer and conductor born in Rio de Janeiro, Francisco composed the Hino Nacional Brasileiro (Brazilian Anthem). He was an active name in musical life in Rio de Janeiro after José Maurício Nunes Garcia's death until the Carlos Gomes' debut. He was named to Brazilian Academy of Music.

Brazilian Emperor and King of Portugal, D. Pedro had a notable sensibility to music. He had classes with José Maurício Nunes Garcia, Marcos Portugal and Sigismund Neukomm. He played the clarinet, basson and cello. Among his works are one Overture, one Credo, one Te Deum and the Hino da Independência do Brasil (Brazilian Independence Anthem).

item.texto: D. Pedro arrives in Brazil with his family. He was 9 years old.
HIs father became King of Portugal and Pedro is now the Royal Prince.
The first six Brazilian waltz are composed by D. Pedro. Later the composer Sigismund Neukomm writes "arranged for orchestra with trios".
D. Pedro receives a command from Portugal to come back to Europe, but he decides stay in Brazil.
Emperor of Brazil during about 9 years, D. Pedro I abdicates the throne in favor of his son, Pedro, a little 5 years old child.
In Europe, D. Pedro meets Rossini, which conducted his work Te Deum in Paris.

descricao: Composer, tenor and violinist best known as the author of popular songs (modinhas). About 1805 he moved from Ouro Preto to Rio de Janeiro. About 1814, composed 3 duets for violins, which are pioneering examples of chamber music practice in Brazil. In 1834, some of his songs are published, at the same time with the beginning of musical impression in Brazil.

item.texto: At the beginning of this decade, he starts studying with Francesco Ignacio Ansaldi for Prince Dom João indication, seeking his further activities at the Bragança's Real Chapel in Rio de Janeiro.

During the regency period (1831-1840) there were no opera presentations in Rio de Janeiro. Trindade worked as a composer, singer and violinist in theater plays and recitals, playing operatic excerpts and instrumental variations.
His first ballroom songs are published at the same time musical press starts in Brazil. That songs have achieved great success and came to be pirated.

descricao: Considered author of the most beautiful and celebrated modinhas and lundus of the First Empire, he was a student of José Maurício Nunes Garcia, with who learned theory and chant. Among his compositions, stand out Lá no Largo da Sé Velha and the modinha Quando as Glórias que Gozei, Both of them were very popular in Rio de Janeiro during the first half of 19th century.

item.titulo: Lá no Largo da Sé Velha

item.texto: He stood out in Rio de Janeiro as a solo tenor of a concert of the society Acadêmicos Filarmônicos, where he had played singing parts and operatic arias.
Cândido asked to Dom Pedro I the nomination as viola of the Imperial Chapel or singer musician in tenor voice.
Participated in a concert realized in the Teatro Constitucional (Constitutional Theatre), organized by the flautist and editor Pierre Laforge.

Alongside Francisco Manuel da Silva founded the Sociedade de Beneficência Musical (Musical Beneficence Society). In the concerts realized there were presented part of his works, including Novas variações para corneta de chaves and Variações para corne inglês, clarineta e flauta, wirh orchestra.

During a gala recital in the Teatro Constitucional Fluminense, by the birthday of Dom Pedro II, was played the Hino das artes created by Cândido Inácio. In the same year, Pierre Laforge's musical publishing company published his 12 Valsas para piano.

nome: Anônimo, obras coletadas por Spix e Von Martius
nome_completo: Anônimo, obras coletadas por Spix e Von Martius
descricao: Between 1817 and 1820, the naturalists Spix and Von Martius traveled several Brazilian regions and collected samples of folk songs and lundus, which were published in their book "Journey to Brazil."

Composer, musician and priest. In his vast work, over than one hundred compositions are known. His Matinas do Natal are rare example of 19th century sacred music of Minas Gerais with printed scores. He is the author of pieces such as Ofício de Ramos, the Ofícios de Trevas and Sexta-Feira Maior which are traditionally performed nowadays in the celebrations of Holy Week in São João del Rei, his hometown, in Minas Gerais.

Brother of composer Alexandre Levy, Luiz studied piano with Gabriel Giraudon, a French teacher that came to São Paulo in 1860. Luiz actively participated in the diffusion process of new Brazilian repertoire for chamber music. Among his vast repertoire are several dances, the 1st Brazilian Rhapsody (dedicated to Leopoldo Miguez) and the 2nd Brazilian Rhapsody (dedicated to Guiomar Novaes).

The first student of the Conservatório de Música do Rio de Janeiro to be sent to Europe to complete their studies, where years later he would be a teacher. He wrote the operas O Vagabundo and La Nuit au Chateau, and the latter was presented in Paris. Operettas and light musical pieces represent most of his productions, among them Ali-Babá, Trunfo às avessas and Coroa de Carlos Magno.

item.texto: Begins his musical studies with Desidério Dorison and, by this time, he was already performing trumpet solos. The following year, he enrolled at Liceu Musical in the same class as Gioacchino Giannini, who would become his teacher at the Conservatório de Música years later.
Around 1854 to 1855, Alves de Mesquita begins his first compositions: the modinha O retrato (1854) and the romance Ilusão (1855), among others.

Graduates from the Conservatório Brasileiro de Música, obtaining a gold medal in counterpoint and organ courses from teacher Gioacchino Giannini, and is the first student to receive a travel award to Europe to improve his skills. His waltz Saudades de Madame Charton and the lundu Beijos de frade are published this year.

Goes to the French capital where he studies harmony, stages the operetta La nuit au chateau, and achieves great success with the quadrille Soirée brésilienne. From Paris, he sends works such as the symphonic overture L'Étoile du Brésil to Rio de Janeiro.

His opera O Vagabundo ou A Infidelidade, sedução e vaidade punidas is presented on the 24th of October at the Teatro Lírico Fluminense with libretto translated by Luis Vicente de Simoni. Obtained success seven years after the opera was restaged in Italian.
Returns to Brazil. In Rio de Janeiro, joins the Alcázar orchestra as a trumpetist.

Assumes the role as conductor of the Teatro fênix Dramática orchestra. There, he presents several successful operettas: Triunfo às avessas (1871), Ali Babá (1872) and Coroa de Carlos Magno (1873), among others.
Is named teacher of solfege and principles of harmony at the Conservatório de Música. From this year until 1886, he also assumes the role of organist at the Church of São Pedro.

Distances himself from theater and continues teaching at the Conservatório de Música. This year, he is made teacher of brass instruments and retires in 1904. By then, the Conservatório de Música is now the Instituto Nacional de Música.

descricao: The most praised Brazilian opera composer, he has been the first to have his works presented on the famous Teatro Alla Scala (Milano), where they have been much acclaimed. One of his main titles is O Guarani, with a libretto based on a book by José de Alencar and which Abertura is a brief introduction of the Brazilian radio program A Voz do Brasil.

item.texto: Composes his first mass, the Saint Sebastian Mass. It was dedicated to his father and was full of mysticism.
It was published A Cayumba. It was one of the first classical works which included a rhythm from afro dances, although the main rhythm is tha Polka.

obras.titulo: Bela ninfa de minh’alma (voz e piano)

item.texto: Inspired by his beloved Ambrosina, Carlos Gomes composes the song Quem sabe.
Composes his first opera – A Noite no Castelo, with lyrics in Portuguese. Its debut in Teatro Lírico was a great succes.
With his second opera Joana de Flandres, he got from the emperor D. Pedro II a scholarship to study in Europe.

In Milan, he starts a brilliant career which its benchmark would be the opera O Guarani, with the Italian script based on the José de Alencar's romance. This opera was first presented in the theatre Alla Scala of Milan. In Brazil, he lived a glorious moment when presented his three operas (O Guarani, Salvador Rosa and Fosca). They were present in concerts in Rio de Janeiro, Salvador and Recife.

item.titulo: Sonata para cordas "O Burrico de Pau"

item.texto: Composes Burrico de Pau, a sonata for the string quintet and quartet.

obras.titulo: Sonata para cordas "O Burrico de Pau"

item.texto: Becomes director of Conservatório de Música de Belém do Pará (Belém do Pará Conservatory of Music).

descricao: Widely famous actor, musician and composer in the 19th century, Xisto Bahia was the composer of famous lundus, such as Isto é bom and Iaiá, você quer morrer. His musical production, of excellent quality and almost always associated with modinha and lundu, has garnered various studies, both for its historical importance as well as for the oral character of its spread.

item.texto: With the death of his father, tries to pursue a career in business. Without success, dedicates himself to a career in theatre.
Contracted by the company Couto Rocha, travels through the north of the country as an actor.
His abolitionist and republican comedy, Duas páginas de um livro, is published in Maranhão.
Debuts with great success in Rio de Janeiro with the Vicente Pinto de Oliveira Company.
His performance in the piece Os perigos do Coronel is applauded by Dom Pedro II. His popularity grows as a lundu composer.
Passes away in Caxambu. His most representative compositions will be recorded by Casa Edison in the begining of the 20th century.

descricao: Conductor, singer, composer, violinist and piano teacher. Raposo left meaningful sacred work – in all, 17 masses, many hymns and prayers of the Holy Week. Tenor of great success in the region where he lived, he earned the nickname of Sabiá Mineiro and had the opportunity to sing for Princess Isabel and D. Pedro II, from whom he received a silver medal and a gold baton.

item.texto: On a visit to the town of Baependi, Princess Isabel and Count d'Eu could hear the tenor Francisco performing the Te Deum during the Mass of Thanksgiving in the Nossa Senhora de Montserrat Church.

Francisco takes part in the "União e Indústria Exhibition" in Juiz de Fora, performing the Hino aos Mineiros of his own authorship. There, the young tenor began to gain visibility and had the opportunity to sing for D. Pedro II in the same solemnity.
As a tenor and composer, Francisco begins to work in the region of Vassouras, Valença and Barra do Piraí. The success of his interpretations gives him the nickname Sabiá Mineiro.

In that year, the newspaper "O Baependyano" points out Francisco Raposo at the head of the religious solemnities ceremonies of Nossa Senhora da Conceição, in the chapel that blessed Francisca de Paula de Jesus - Nhá Chica built with the help of devotees.
Although much of the repertoire left by Francisco Raposo is sacred pieces, it dates from this year a profane autograph score: the Cateretê, written for two women voices and orchestra.

The musicological discoveries of the second half of the twentieth century in Minas Gerais connect Francisco Raposo to the Carlos Gomes Musical Coorporation in 1892. In that year his adopted son, Emílio do Patrocínio Nogueira (1888-1969), began his musical studies at this Corporation. There Emílio became a master and was a regent for more than 50 years.

The newspaper O País, from Rio de Janeiro, reports that Francisco went to this city to buy an organ for the Nossa Senhora da Conceição Chapel under orders of Blessed Nhá Chica, but he could not even get a note in the organ on the day of its inauguration. Nhá Chica guaranteed that organ would work again next day. The prediction was confirmed and gave rise to stories about the "Organ's miracle".

The book "A música, a vida e a obra de Francisco Raposo" (Music, life and work of Francisco Raposo) authored by Miranda Pontes, Turri Nicoliello and Salomé Oliveira is published by Fumbec-Baependi Editors.
Under initiative of the Musical Corporation Carlos Gomes, from Baependi, for the first time a CD with compositions by Francisco Raposo is recorded.

descricao: Brazilian composer and diplomat. Brasílio was the first to incorporate folk themes in classical music in Brazil. He became good friends with some of the greatest pianists of his time, such as Anton Rubinstein. He is the 19th patron of Academia Brasileira de Música (Brazilian Academy of Music). Among his main works and compositions, the one that stands out is A sertaneja (1869), considered the first Brazilian nationalist composition.

item.texto: At the time when he entered the faculty of law in São Paulo, he already was a prominent pianist.

Composes A Sertaneja that is considered one of the first examples of using traditional Brazilian themes in the concert music. In this composition, the composer used a traditional brazilian song: Balaio, meu bem, balaio.

Receives an invitation from princess Isabel to enter the diplomatic service. He occupies different diplomatic positions around Europe. His work in diplomacy did not interfere his commitment to music. On the occasion of gathering in his residence in Italy, three greatest pianists of that time: Anton Rubinsten, Giovanni Sgambati and Franz Liszt, he performed A Sertaneja.
Dies in Berlin, germany. He is chosen as the 19th patron of Academia Brasileira de Música (Brazilian Academy of Music).

descricao: Composer, instrumentalist and conductor. She was the biggest female personality in Brazilian music's history and one of the greatest expressions in fight for freedom in the country.

item.texto: At the age of 11 she composes her first song, a Christmas carol named Canção dos Pastores (Shepherd's Song).
Chiquinha marries an officer of the Merchant Marine, Jacinto Ribeiro do Amaral, chosen by her parents. She divorced him a few years later.
Chiquinha made her debut as a composer with a polka called Atraente.
At São Pedro de Alcântara Theatre, Chiquinha promotes and conducts a guitar concert, a stigmatized instrument at the time.
Chiquinha composes the first "marcha-rancho", Ó Abre Alas, which became an anthem of the Brazilian carnival.
Composes Lua Branca.
Creates the Brazilian Society of Theater Artists (SBAT), the first union to protect copyrights in the country.
Aged 85, she writes her final score, Maria, with a libretto by Viriato Corrêa.
Chiquinha passes away aged 87. Her work brings together dozens of scores for theatrical plays and hundreds of songs in various musical genres.

descricao: Composer and flautist, he is considered the father of choro. He was creator of Choro Carioca, first instrumental ensemble to use the flute, cavaquinho and the guitar together. He became the most popular instrumentalist in Rio de Janeiro in the Empire. Flor Amorosa, his greatest success, became known as the first composed choro.

item.texto: He begins his studies in composition and conducting with Henrique Alves de Mesquita.
Callado makes his first appearance in concert halls, presenting himself as the 2nd flautist in the Gymnasium Dramatic Theatre.
At age of 19, he obtains his first success as a composer: a quadrilha (square dance) named Carnaval de 1867.
The first polka by Callado is published: Querida por todos, dedicated to Chiquinha Gonzaga.
Founds the group Choro Carioca.
He becomes flute professor at the Brazilian Conservatory of Music.
The polka Cruzes, minha prima! is published and obtains great popularity.
Along with other teachers of Brazilian Conservatory, he receives the Ordem da Cruz Rosa, one of the highest distinctions of the Empire.

descricao: Composer, violinist and Brazilian conductor, author of the Hino da Proclamação da República. He was the first director of the Instituto Nacional de Música (current Escola de Música da UFRJ). Among this work, the following symphonic poems deserve to be highlighted: Parisina, Ave, Liberta! and Prometeu, the opera Os saldunes (Coelho Neto lyrics) and Sinfonia em si bemol.

item.texto: Leopoldo began his musical studies in Porto, Portugal, and at the age of 21 he returned to Brazil.
He partnered Artur Napoleão and they created a company of pianos and score sale. At the age of 32 years old he went to Europe in order to become more refined as a musician.
He came back to Brazil where he got influenced by the musical language of Wagner and from which has never set apart.
Composes Sonata para violino e piano.
He gained a prominent position with his piece Poemas Sinfônicos Parisina.
He was nominated the first director of the recently founded Instituto Nacional de Música, becoming a remarkable manager. Composes the symphonic poem Ave, Libertas!
Composes his third symphonic poem, Prometheus.
He travelled to several European countries in order to get to know the teaching methods of these countries.

item.titulo: Sonata para violino e piano - opus 14

item.texto: He died at the age of 52 in Rio de Janeiro.
His family moved to Spain and then to Portugal.

descricao: He was one of the most important composers of his generation. Although he composed music mainly for piano, he was also seduced by all of classical music genres, such as orchestral concerts, compositions for violin and cello, chamber music - like trios, quartets or quintets, operas and impressive collection of church music, for example songs for voice and piano.

item.texto: Jean-Jacques, his father, establishes a piano shop in São Paulo. Henrique, who has already started piano lessons with his mother, has a constant contact with the instrument that becomes sort of a toy to him.
Still a boy, Henrique Oswald presented his talent in front of a big audience with a great success. He becomes a student of Gabriel Giraudon that was considered the best professor in the city.

Travels with his mother to Europe and enters Instituto Moriani in Florence, Italy, to study counterpoint, harmony and composition with professors Maglioni and Grazzini, and piano with Henry Ketten and Giuseppe Buonamici.

Receives a scholarship of 100 frank granted by the Emperor Peter II who was passing by Florence and had opportunity to meet Henrique Oswald. The composer dedicated a recital to him. Henrique composes Berceuse for piano and cello.
Composes Quinteto opus 18 em dó maior for chamber orchestra.
Has the opportunity to play piano duet with Camile Saint-Saens - the composition Scherzo, a work of this French composer who was very impressed by Henrique Oswald.
Composes Sinfonia opus 27 in honour of the president Rodrigues Alves.

Goes back to Brazil, accompanied by his wife and cellist Cinganelli to show his music and see again his homeland. He makes a great success both in São Paulo and in Rio de Janeiro, and he is praised by the critics in Brazil.
Composes Elegia para violoncelo e piano dedicated to Henrico Mariotti in memorian.
He is nominated by the president Campos Sales (who has met him in Florence) chancellor of Brazil in the Consulate in Le Havre.

Receives one of the most important European prizes for his works Le fate and Il neige!, that were competing with 647 manuscripts from different countries from Asia, two Americas, Europe and from Persia and Egypt.
He is nominated Director of Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music) in Rio de Janeiro by the Baron of Rio Branco. He remains in this position until 1906.
Presents himself in Munich, with his compositions chamber ensembles and solo piano.
Receives a formal invitation to take over as a professor a seat in Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music). Definitely settles in Brazil. Did not return to Italy anymore.

Plays his Concerto para Piano e Orquestra in Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music) conducted by the running Director of the Institute, Alberto Nepomuceno. At that time, composes his Sinfonia, Opus 43.

His Sinfonia opus 43 is played for the first time with Marinuzzi as a conductor ahead of Orquestra do Teatro Colon (Orchestra of Colon theatre) of Buenos Aires, in the Municipal Theatre in Rio de Janeiro. At that time, he writes Andante con Variazioni that dedicates to his son, Alfredo.
Receives Médaille du Roi Albert (avec ruban striié d'une rayure), granted by the Government of Belgium.
Despite of common excitement about the Modern Art Week, Henrique stands aside. He accepts the "modernisms" but doesn't join them.
Great festivities mark the passing of his 79th birthday. Play of his works, parties, banquets, honours.

A few days before the composer's death, Ambassador of France in Brazil, Count Dejean, informs Oswald that his country had decided to award him the title of Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur. Henrique dies before receiving it. He was honoured by the Ambassador of France at the funeral.

descricao: One of the first Brazilian composers to cross the boundary between classical and popular music, he wrote mainly for his instrument, the piano. His work is remarkably original with respect to style and rhythmic invention. All his 211 pieces are available in this website.

item.texto: Ernesto loses his mom, also his first piano teacher, which affects him greatly. Trying to support the musical vocation of his son his father finds a new teacher, Eduardo Madeira.
At age of 15, he starts to compose the waltz O nome dela, finished in 1886. The score was published only in 2008.

His third piece is published, the polka Cruz Perigo!!. The melody in the right hand already implies the articulation widespread in the Nazareth's works. The polka Gracietta dedicated to his godfather is also published this year.

At the age of 17 he publishes the polka Gentes! O Imposto Pegou?. The title refers to a tax that caused the famous protest "Revolta do Vintém". Also this year the polka Não caio n'outra!!! was published. The piece was his first big success.
Nazareth marries Theodora Amália with whom he had four children.
The quadrilha A flor de meus sonhos is published by Pereira Braga and Company. This year his first daughter was born.
His second child is born this year. He has 3 polkas published by Pereira & Araújo: A Bela Melusina, Nazareth and A Fonte do Lambary.

He writes the polka-lundu Eulina in honour of his daughter. He also composes the polka Atrevidinha, dedicated to his friend Levindo de Araújo, and Chile-Brasil, a quadrilha dedicated to the Chilean fleet of ships that landed in Rio de Janeiro this year.

Composes the polka-tango Rayon d'or, the first piece to contain the word "tango" in its subtitle, the genre that Nazareth would develop in an exceptional way with close to 90 pieces. This first tango was dedicated to pianist Alberto Motta.

He composes Brejeiro, his first Brazilian tango, dedicated to his nephew Gilberto Nazareth. It was his biggest success during his life and one of the great success of Brazilian music of the19th century. In addition, he composes the waltz Julieta, dedicated to his friend Luiz Ferreira Campos.

He writes Marietta, a polka dedicated to his daughter Maria de Lourdes. This year he begins working as a pianist for the Casa Vieira Machado & Cia. In the following years he works in other establishments not only a demonstrator pianist but also writes and reviews scores.

He performs for the first time in public at Clube São Cristóvão playing a piece considered close to the classic style, Adieu, among others. He composes the tangos Está chumbado and Furinga. This year he also wirtes the schottisch Gentil, dedicated to all the Brazilian girls.

Composes the schottosch Arrufos. The tango Digo was dedicated to Constança Teixeira and the waltz Dora was dedicated to his wife Theodora. He also dedicated the waltz Elite-club to his friend Jovino Barral and the waltz Genial to poet Arthur Azevedo. This year was published Julieta e Onze de maio.
He begins to compose Batuque, a tango finished around 1908. The title refers to the African dances.

Composes the waltz Coração que sente and two tangos: Pyrilampo and Thierry. He is invited by Alberto Nepomuceno to graduate by Instituto Nacional de Música, but refuses the offer considering himself very old to this.

The tangos Escovado e Ferramenta are published. In the score of the last one, below author's name appears the words "Tango's King". Casa Edison launches a disc with the tango Brejeiro, with lyrics by Catullo da Paixão Cearense sung by Mário Pinheiro.
At the age of 44 and working at Tesouro Nacional he composes the only maxixe of his work, Dengoso.
Nazareth works again as a pianist demonstrator at Casa Mozart. He is invited by Alberto Nepomuceno to perform playing his pieces in the National Exhibition.

Nazareth performs at Instituto Nacional de Música playing some of his works and a dueto with Villa-Lobos, with whom he played Le cygne, by Saint-Saëns, for cello and piano. This year he begins working as a pianist at Cinema Odeon.
The Brazilian tango Odeon is published. The piece would be recorded by him in 1912 and would become a great success.
The polka Ameno Resedá, dedicated to the homonimous carnival group, is published by Casa Arthur Napoleão.
A catalog with 19 compositions by Nazareth is released by Casa Beethoven. It is also published the first edition of polka Apanheite-te cavaquinho, another success composed by him.

He writes Insuperável, a tango dedicated to his friend Orlando Pires de Moraes. Composes Suculento, dedicated to the carnival groups and the tango Sustenta a... nota... He is also invited by composer and pianist Eduardo Souto to work as a pianist demonstrator at Casa Carlos Gomes.
Villa-Lobos dedicated to Nazareth his Choros nº 1, for guitar.

obras.titulo: Hino da escola Bernardo de Vasconcellos

item.texto: At age of 60, he publishes his Improviso, a piece dedicated to Villa-Lobos. He composes the tango Escorregando, the anthems Hino da escola Esther Pedreira de Mello, o Hino da Escola Floriano Peixoto and the tango Tudo sobe!

obras.titulo: Hino da escola Esther Pedreira de Mello

item.texto: Nazareth goes to São Paulo in a tour sponsored by local admirers. He performs at Theatro Municipal and Conservatório Dramático e Musical, playing his compositions. He also visited and played in Campinas, Sorocaba and Tatuí, cities in São Paulo state.

After being for eleven months in São Paulo, Nazareth comes back to Rio. During this period he composed the tangos Cruzeiro, Cubanos and Paraíso and the waltz Faceira. He arrives with a piano Sanzin offered by public of São Paulo. This year he also wirtes Dor Secreta, Encantador and Marcha Fúnebre.
Two works of Nazareth are recorded by Francisco Alves and Vicente Celestino. He composes Cavaquinho, por que choras? dedicated to Aracy Nazareth Montel and Ipanema, dedicated to military bands.
Eduardo Souto, artistic director of Odeon-Parlophon Company, invites Nazareth to record Apanhei-te, cavaquinho, Escovado, Nenê and Turuna. The composer writes Resignação, his last composition.

descricao: He was born in Maranhão and at the age of 17 moved with his family to Rio de Janeiro. in the capital, he started to meet with musicians such as Anacleto de Medeiros and Sátiro Bilhar, that were playing the Brazilian music style called choro. He is considered one of the most famous folk poets of Brazil, having written lyrics for Luar do Sertão by João Pernabuco and Flor Amorosa by Joaquim Callado.

item.texto: Moves with his family to Rio de Janeiro. Catullo becomes friends with a music student, Anacleto de Medeiros, the flutist Viriato Figueira da Silva and the violonist Quincas Laranjeira. a fruit of his musical meetings and serenades played across Rio de Janeiro is his first composition, a lyrical song (modinha) Ao Luar.

Performs his first recital in the National Institute of Music. Plying guitar and singing songs with lyrics written by him, receives an ovation from the public and critics. In September, makes an appearance in the João Caeano Theatre where, again, he is received very well by the public.
Composes together with João Pernambuco, Cabocla di Caxangá and Luar do Sertão. The latter, considered the second national anthem for a long time, is one of the most famous folk songs in Brazil.

Catullo is invited by D. Nair, wife of the president Hermes da Fonseca, to perform in the Catete Palace, where he receives a standing ovation. Such a sensational feat is considered a "liberating moment in the Brazilian music"and earned him a public office in the National Press. His latest composition, Luar do Sertão (created together with João Pernambuco), was included in his repertoire.

A researcher, Haroldo Costa. releases in the Museum of the Republic a book "Catulo da Paixão - Life and work", in which the author speaks about the life and work of the great serenade writer and poet.

descricao: Considered one of the most prominent Brazilian nationalist composers, he defended the use of Portuguese language in classical music. He believed that “a people who do not sing in their own language do not have a homeland”.

item.texto: His father decides to move the family to Recife, where the young Alberto would have more opportunities to develop his musical studies.

At the age of 18, he assumes the position of concert director at Clube Carlos Gomes de Recife. Performs as a violinist at the opening night of the opera Leonor by Euclides Fonseca, at Teatro Santa isabel.
As an adolescent, he develops friendships with students and teachers from the Faculty of Law in Recife, including Tobias Barreto, Alfredo Pinto, Clóvis Bevilácqua and Farias Brito.

Having been denied government funding to further his studies in Europe, probably because of his abolitionist activities, he moves to Rio de Janeiro and stays with the painter Bernardelli and his family. On 1 November, he makes his Rio debut at the Beethoven Club, performing alongside cellist Frederico Nascimento, who eventually becomes a close friend.

A year prior to the abolition of slavery, he writes Dança de Negros, one of the first compositions to feature Afro-Brazilian motifs.These would later be incorporated into Série brasileira (Brazilian Series) as Batuque. The work is first performed on 25 April, 1888 in Fortaleza.

Lacking support from the Brazilian government to finance a trip to Europe, he embarks on a tour of Northeast Brazil to raise funds. In August, he leaves Brazil to study in Rome and is accompanied by Rodolfo and Henrique Bernardelli, who support him in his endeavor.

obras.titulo: Porangaba (suíte): I Preludio (1º ato); II Dança dos Índios; III Entreato (3º ato); IV Bailado

item.texto: In Rome, he writes his first string quartets, which he never gets to hear performed during his lifetime.

item.titulo: Suite antique opus 11: I Prélude; II Air; III.Menuet; IV.Rigaudon
Quatro peças líricas opus 13: I Anhelo; II Valsa; III Diálogo; IV Galhofeira

item.texto: Appointed professor at Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music). Before returning to Brazil, visits Paris, where he attends the world premiere of Debussy's Prélude à l'après-midi d'un faune, a work that would later be performed in Brazil. Composes the nationalist-inspired A Galhofeira, featuring rhytms typical of urban music.

obras.titulo: Quatro peças líricas opus 13: I Anhelo; II Valsa; III Diálogo; IV Galhofeira
Ora dize-me a verdade opus 12 nº 1

item.texto: Back in Brazil, he presents a series of his own songs (in Portuguese) at a concert at the National Institute of Music. This marks a hard-fought campaign to promote the use of Portuguese in classical music. A violent battle ensues with the most famous critic of the era, Oscar Guanabarino, who defends the use of Italian in choral singing.

The fight over nationalization in classical music spreads as he becomes involved in the activities of Associação de Concertos Populares (Association of Popular Concerts), which he directs for 10 years.

Presents is main symphonic works Sinfonia em sol menor, Epitalâmio (in a version for choir and archestra), Suíte antiga, As Uiaras and Série Brasileira (composed of four parts: Alvorada na Serra, Intermédio, A sesta na rede and Batuque) for the first time in Brazil. Série Brasileira causes a scandal among mainstream critics of the time for its use of reco-reco, a folkloric instrument.
The Garatuja, an opera named after José de Alencar's similarly titled work, is considered the first truly Brazilian opera in terms of music, setting and use of the Portuguese language.
Publication of a collection of 12 songs in Portuguese, edited by Vieira Machado & Moreira de Sá.

Begins rewriting the Hino Nacional (both music and text), which eventually comes under the authorship of Osório Duque Estrada. Although a competition is held for a new melody, Francisco Manoel da Silva's original version is preserved.

At the National Institute of Music, where he serves as director, he promotes a recital of works by the composer Catulo da Paixão Cearense, which is well received by critics and the general public. That year, he is selected to conduct 26 concerts at the National Exhibition in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the opening of the ports.
As a supporter of naitonal talents, he, along with Sampaio Araújo, becomes involved in publishing the works of an up-and-coming composer by the name of Heitor Villa-Lobos.
Dies in Rio de Janeiro in October.

descricao: Son of the owner of Casa Levy, which sold sheet music and pianos in São Paulo, Alexandre Levy was naturally inclined toward music. From an early age he showed a remarkable talent for the piano. He often used folk themes in his compositions, which is why he is considered a nationalist composer.

item.texto: Son of the French immigrant and Casa Levy's founder Henrique Levy, Alexandre performed for the first time at 8. He was compared to Mozart for his precocity and brilliance.
At the age of 16, Alexandre begin to publish his compositions by European publishers.
On the occasion of the foundation of the Clube Haydn, in São Paulo, Alexandre was chosen like director of concerts.

item.titulo: Variações sobre um tema popular brasileiro

item.texto: He begins to compose the Sinfonia em mi menor. In the following year he travels to Europe and composes his Variations sur un thème populaire brésilien (the "Vem cá, Bitu").

Alexandre goes to the France to study with Émile Durand and Vincenzo Ferroni. This was an important step to his intellectual development. He soon returned to Brazil and started his activities as a musical critic in São Paulo. Alexandre abandoned in part his romanticism and became in favor of modernity, both as composer as a musical critic.

Debut his Samba, the first work that would divulgue in Brazil what until then was only known as slaves danse. The work was very well received by public and received applause. Samba is part of a four movements piece, the Suíte brésilienne (Prelúdio; Dança rústica; À beira do regato; Samba).

descricao: Engineer, mathematician, philologist, poet, composer, conductor, arranger, orchestrator, musician, teacher and author of articles for magazines and newspapers in the country and abroad. His legacy earned him several honors, as the book - Fróes, um Notável Músico Baiano - and a CD that rescued a part of his valuable collection of 13 compositions, among them: Evocation, Opus 4; Un Petit Cimetiêre.

Anacleto learned music while playing the piccolo at the Banda da Companhia do Arsenal de Guerra. He conducted and organized several bands, among them the one from textile factories in Bangu and Macacos, the Piedade Band and the Sociedade Recreio Musical Paquetaense. As the director of the Banda do Corpo de Bombeiros (The Fire Department Band), he was responsible for the recording of one of the first albums ever produced in Brazil. As a composer he created several polkas, xotes and waltzes.

item.texto: He graduated from the Conservatory of Music and although mastering various wind instruments, his favourite was the soprano saxophone. Shortly afterwards he founded the Sociedade Recreio Musical Paquetaense with some of the musicians from the Banda de Paquetá, which had been discontinued.
He started to organize the Banda do Corpo de Bombeiros which became famous under his direction for having been responsible for recording some of the first records pressed in Brazil.
The Banda do Corpo de Bombeiros recorded his waltz Farrula for Odeon.
Through the initiative of the painter and sculptor Pedro Bruno, one of the streets of the island Paquetá was named Maestro Anacleto.

The Banda do Corpo de Bombeiros recorded the polkas Lídia and Três estrelinhas, the xote Implorando and the dobrado (a quick march) Jubileu dos Bombeiros do Rio, composed in tribute to the corporation.
The Banda do Corpo de Bombeiros recorded the xote Não me olhes assim and the waltzes Predileta and Terna saudade on Victor Records.

descricao: A student of the Imperial Music Conservatoire, Francisco Braga was a very active conductor - whether it is for orchestras or military bands. From 1902 he taught counterpoint, fugue and composition at the National Institute of Music. The notable pieces of his orchestral work include Prelúdio, Variações sobre um tema brasileiro and A Toada (for cello and orchestra).

item.texto: Started his musical education at the Asilo dos Meninos Desvalidos where he took later the direction of the musical ensemble.
Braga was laureate of the competition to select the new national anthem. He was awarded a studentship to be a student of Massenet's at Conservatoire of Paris.

Composes Episódio Sinfônico, dedicated to Dr. José Rodrigues de Azevedo Pinheiro, his master and friend. Then he created the opera Jupira with a Wagnerian influence, that was staged two years later at the Lyrical Theater in Rio de Janeiro with great success.
Composes the symphonic poems Paysage, Cauchemar and Marabá.
Braga became teacher of counterpoint, fugue and composition at the National Institute of Music.
Writes Variações sobre um tema brasileiro.
Composes the Hino à Bandeira, with lyrics by Olavo Bilac, upon an order by Pereira Passos for the National Flag raising ceremonies in public schools in Rio de Janeiro.
Conducts the concert for the inauguration of the Municipal Theatre of Rio de Janeiro and presents his symphonic poem Insônia.
Composes Trio for piano, violin and cello.

After he died is appointed Patron of chair n.32 in the Brazilian Academy of Music. The notable pieces of his orchestral work include Prelúdio, Variações sobre um tema brasileiro and A Toada, the latter for cello and orchestra.

descricao: Meneleu Campos exerted intense artistic activity in Belém and he was director of the Carlos Gomes Institute (1900-1906). Between his activities are a curriculum reform, the promotion of concerts and the organization of an orchestra, a quartet and a choir. He is the authot of chamber and symphonic music that most distinguishes between paraenses composers. He left an extensive vocal work.

item.texto: He has his first published compositions.
He left the law school that was attending in Recife and traveled to Milan, where he attended the Royal Conservatory of Music.
Returns to Belém where he assumed the directorship of the Carlos Gomes Institute and also debuted as a conductor at Teatro da Paz.
Premiere of the work Un sogno at Catedral de Belém, performed by Carlos Gomes Institute 65 voices choir conducted by Ettore Bosio.
He traveled again to Europe and, in Milan, held concerts at the Liceo Beccaria and at the Royal Conservatory. Upon returning to Belém reassumed the direction of the Institute until 1906.
Returned to Paris and after moves to Portugal, where he lived for 2 years and worked as a teacher.

nascimento.local: Santa Rita do Passa Quatro, SP

descricao: Flutist and composer, Patápio Silva was one of the forerunners of Choro. After playing in bands in various cities in the countryside he became the conductor of the Lira Guarani. In Rio de Janeiro he was accepted into the Flute course at the Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music). Contracted by Casa Edison he recorded various works that stayed two decades in catalogue. He also performed in the Palacio do Catete for the President Afonso Pena.

item.texto: He joins the Cataguases Band playing flute.
He becomes conductor of Lira Guarani in Campos.
He moves to Rio de Janeiro where he sits the entrance exam and is accepted at the Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music) enrolling directly into third year.
In two years he finishes the course that normally takes 6 years graduating with distinctions and furthermore wins a special competition.
He performs his first recital alongside students from the Instituto Nacional de Música and contracted by Fred Figner from Casa Edison records pioneering records in Brazil.
He records the walz Amor perdido and the polka Zinha which he wrote. He performs his first presentation in São Paulo at the Salão Steinway. In June he performs in Santos.
He moves to São Paulo where he organises a presentation in the Salão do Conservatório Dramático e Musical (Drama and Music Conservatory) and performs recitals in the countryside cities of the state.
While travelling to Florianópolis (SC) for a concert, Patápio becomes ill and dies on the 24th of April.
His compositions Fantasia de concerto n.1 and Fantasia de concerto n. 2 are recorded by Ladário Teixeira on saxophone.
Altamiro Carrilho records the  LP Revivendo Patápio (Reliving Patápio).
The flutist Lenir Siqueira records the LP Relembrando Patápio (Remembering Patápio) accompanied on piano by Alceu Bocchino.

descricao: Pianist and composer. He integrated a trio together with Humberto Milano (violin) and Alfredo Gomes (cello), with whom he realized presentations disseminating the repertoire of chamber music of Brazilian composers. In 1906, he begins his activities as a professor at the National Institute of Music.

João Pernambuco was one of the guitar Brazilian schools's creators. He was born in Jatobá, a city in Pernambuco State. His father was a Portuguese, while his mother was an Indian Caeté. At the age of 20, he moved to Rio de Janeiro carrying only his guitar and some clothes. Supported by Catulo da Paixão Cearence, Quincas Laranjeiras and Ernani Figueiredo, he went to the Instituto Nacional de Música. Villa-Lobos was one of his admirers. João Pernambuco composed many classic songs like Luar do Sertão, Magoado and Pó de Mico, among others.

item.texto: At the age of 12 João was already playing the viola, an instrument similar to the guitar, which he learned from some viola's players and wilderness singers.

He moved to Rio de Janeiro, where he begun living with his sister and worked in a foundry. Six years later he started to work as a servant in the Rio de Janeiro's city hall. Besides his modest culture, he had an exceptional musical talent and started to share his time with some popular guitar players to improve his skills with the instrument.

He had already composed some songs, toadas and toadas-sertanejas and knew many others from the northeastern folklore. By that time he met Catulo da Paixão Cearense, with who he begun to compose songs based in those folklore like Engenho de Humaitá. That song became later the famous toada Luar do sertão.

This year was published the piece Luar do Sertão, considered the Brazilian Northeast hymn. Unfortunately, the melody authorship of João Pernambuco wasn't credited by his partner Catullo da Paixão Cearense.

His song Caboca di Caxangá (1913) did a huge success during the Carnival. It was João's idea to form a group of Caxangá, creating a new musical style in Brazil. The members wore clothes from Brazilian Northeast and played typical instruments, and was formed by João, Pixinguinha, Nelson Alves, Donga and others when it was on its best moment.

descricao: Composer, pianist, soloist and conductor. Graduated in Music at the Royal Conservatory of Leipzig, Germany. His work is based of German composers such as Bach, Beethoven and Brahms, with strong influences of Wagnerian modernism. His Quarteto de Cordas em Lá maior has classicism aspects plus a few moments of Vivaldi's style, and ends the 4th movement with a folkloric theme from Belém do Pará.

Glauco Velásquez's brief life did not hinder his being considered by his peers as one of the most talented Brazilian composers. His style is unique, quite original for his time, his accords most audacious. He left 123 pieces, mostly for piano and voice and piano, and an unfinished opera. Dismayed by his untimely death caused by tuberculosis, his fellow composers founded the Glauco Velásquez Society to make his work known.

item.texto: Enrolls in the National Institute of Music, where he first studies with Arnaud Gouveia (theory) and Frederico Nascimento (choral singing). Further, he has classes with Francisco Braga (counterpoint, fughe and composition). Quite precocious, he gains the admiration of his teachers, oftentimes being excused from exams.
In this year he composes the piece Salutaris. Resumes his studies at the Music Institute, to study harmony with Frederico Nascimento, a major influence in his aesthetic development.

Composes Brutto Sogno, the highlight of his achievements for piano pieces, which shows some of his most progressive harmonic procedures. The pieces that follow, such as Valsa romântica and Scherzo, show several new phases of his development, unfortunately prematurely interrupted.
Presents, for the first time, a concert with his own pieces, at the auditorium of Jornal do Comércio, sparking off the interest of critics and public alike.
After his death, Luciano Gallet founds the Glauco Velásquez Society and manages to keep his name alive at least for a brief period of time, from 1914 to 1918.

descricao: Considered the greatest Brazilian composer of the Americas, Heitor Villa-Lobos composed close to 2000 works during his lifetime. Among other aspects, he extensively used Brazilian folkloric themes in his works, making him the greatest exponent of musical nationalism, as well as has been influenced by Bach when writing the Bachianas.It was also through Villa-Lobos that Brazilian music became known worldwide.

item.texto: From the age of six started learning with his father how to play the clarinet and cello. At the time, he becomes fascinated with the works of Johann Sebastian Bach, the composer who would eventually inspire the creation of one of his most important cycles, the nine Brazilian Bachianas.

Villa-Lobos meets Quincas Laranjeiras and begins to frequent the music store Cavaquinho de Ouro, a haven for the choro musicians of that era: Luis de Sousa, Anacleto, Irineu de Almeida, Juca Kalut. This would have a great influence on him and be manifested in his later works.
Begins a series of trips throughout Brazil, including the Amazon region, which he later says would have a profound impact on his work.
Back to the Rio de Janeiro, he meets the person he is to eventually marry: Lucília Guimarães.
This year marks the beginning of Villa-Lobos's official debut as a composer, with a series of concerts in Rio de Janeiro. He composes Élégie.
He composes the Amazonas and Uirapuru ballets, which bear the influence of Puccini, Wagner and, most importantly, Stravinsky.

obras.titulo: Quatro canções da floresta do Amazonas

item.texto: As a result of his involvement with the choro, he begins to compose a cycle of fourteen pieces, for various musical formations, entitled Choros. What emerge from this is a new musical form, in which urban music is fused with modern compositional techniques.
Invited by Graça Aranha, Villa-Lobos agrees to participate in three performances at Modern Art Week, presenting Danças Características Africanas (Characteristic African Dances), and other works.
In his first trip to Paris he is introduced to the country's artistic scene through Tarsila do Amaral and other Brazilian fine artists.
In his second trip to the French capital, he presents his compositions in recitals and conducts orchestras in Europe's most important capitals, garnering international acclaim.

Villa-Lobos returns to Brazil for a brief period to perform a concert in São Paulo. Concerned about the lack of respect paid to music in Brazilian schools, he presents a plan on Musical Education to São Paulo's Secretary of Education.
He organizes a choral concert entitled Civic Exhortation, with nearly 12,000 voices and brings together São Paulo residents from all social classes.

Villa-Lobos is officially invited by Anísio Teixeira, the Secretary of Education of Rio de Janeiro, to organize and direct the Superintendence of Musical and Artistic Education (SEMA), which introduces the teaching of music and choral singing to schools.
Departs for Europe to attend the International Congress in Music Education in Prague as Brazil's representative.

item.titulo: Bachianas brasileiras n.5 (versão para voz e piano)

item.texto: Establishes the National Conservatory of Choral Singing, whose objectives were: to train candidates to become choral teachers in primary and secondary schools; to study and prepare guidelines for teaching choral singing in Brazil; to promote work on Brazilian musicology; and to develop recordings, etc.
Villa-Lobos, cajoled by maestro Leopold Stokowski, accepts an invitation from the American maestro Werner Janssen to do a tour in the United States.
In New York, undergoes surgery for the first time to treat a problem that would take his life twelve years later. Recovers and regains his strength to compose.

Travels to Paris, where he records some of his most important works, conducts the ONRTF (Orchestre national de la Radio-télévision française) and records more than seven hours of music. Remastered in the 1990s, the recordings are currently available in CD.

In the final decade of his life, he composes his last five symphonies, his last string quartets, almost all of his concertos (except the first one for piano and the first for cello), the opera Yerma, the suite A Floresta do Amazonas and various chamber works, including Fantasia Concertante for Cellos.
Conducts his last recording, Floresta do Amazonas, at the helm of the Sympohny of the Air. Returns to Rio de Janeiro, where he dies several months later at his home.

descricao: A pionner of "samba amaxixado" in Rio, he was a composer, a pianist and a flautist. The acclaimed "King of Samba" has left about 150 compositions, amongst which are classics like Jura and Gosto que me enrosco. He has left a great legacy which is one of his most important musical collection from the beginning of the 20th century.

item.texto: As young as 17 years old, he marries a Portuguese girl called Henriqueta Ferreira, with whom he would have 3 children. At age 26 he would become a widower.
He starts playing the piano professionally animating the ballrooms of dance associations such as Dragão Clube Universal and Tome a bença Vovó.
He composes his first samba hit, Quem são eles, which originated from a controversy with the group of musicians Donga and Pixinguinha.
Release of 2 very popular songs for carnival of that year: O Pé de anjo - a satire of violonist and singer China, the brother of Pixinguinha, and Fala meu louro, a satire of Rui Barbosa.

Composes the carnival tune Fala baixo, a satire of the government official Artur bernardes, which turns to his own disvantadge as he is persecuted by the police. He hides for a while at his mum's house, in Rio suburb of Engenho de Dentro.

He composes another two classic samba pieces: Ora vejam só, with Francisco Alves singing it, and A favela vai abaixo, which os a criticism of the urban reforms happening at the time which included the demolition of the favela.
He starts teaching Mario Reis how to play the guitar. Mario will become one of the main singers of his songs and responsible for the release of classics such as Jura and Gosto que me enrosco.
Performs at Teatro Municipal de São Paulo, releasing one of his last sambas: Cansei.

descricao: Brazilian composer, pianist, conductor and folklorist, born in Rio de Janeiro. He was an interpreter and the main advocate of the work of Glauco Velásquez and founded a society named after the composer. He also promoted the campaign that result in the foundation of the Associação Brasileira de Música (Brazilian Association of Music).

item.texto: Between the ages of eight and fourteen, he participated in school performances as a singer, actor and pianist at Colégio Pedro II, where he studied.

Enrols at the Instituto Nacional de Música (National Institute of Music), where he studies piano with Henrique Oswald and Abdon Milanez, and harmony with Agnelo França. Founds the Glauco Velásquez Society for the dissemination of the work of that composer who passed way prematurely.
Studies harmony with Darius Milhaud, which puts him in contact with modern French music.
Becomes a performer of the work of Glauco Velásquez and starts his composing career.
In the year of the Modern Art Week, he conducts the choir and the orchestra of the National Institute of Music in Rio de Janeiro in several performances.
Founds the choir society Pró-Arte.
Releases his most famous written work, in five volumes, Canções Populares Brasileiras. Becomes the artistic director of the music magazine Weco. He also composes the work Turuna.
Composes Suíte sobre themas negro-brasileiros, his most important instrumental work.
Becomes the director of the National Institute of Music, where he introduced a series of changes and retained this position until his death.

nome_completo: Jayme Rojas de Aragón y Ovalle
descricao: Jaime moved to Rio de Janeiro in the 1910's and he used to visit the neighborhoods of Lapa and Glória, where he met friends in some cafes that were a refuge of intellectuals and journalists. He became known for his peculiar manner of playing the guitar. His style was highly praised by Sinhô and Pixinguinha. He belongs to the 2nd generation of nationalist composers.

item.texto: In Rio de Janeiro, Ovalle is appointed to work in the National Press after recommendation of the senator Artur de Souza Lemos. Being almost 17 years that time, he had to forge a birth certificate, dated from 5. August 1892, what gave him the age of majority.

In addition to being a composer, Ovalle also wrote poetry and was a friend of Manuel Bandeira who describes his influence on the modernist generation of 1922 and on the artist who succeeded it, claiming that Ovalle would have been a “marginal element” for the modernist movement, which acted contaminating his friends and militants with his "federatively Brazilian personality".

Bandeira, dealing with Ovalle's compositions, says that he had a guaranted immortality as an author of song Azulão, and that this piece “represents in the Brazilian music what in poetry is represented by Canção do Exílio (Song of exile). In the lyrics of Gonçalves Dias, as well as in the melody of Ovalle, there is an ineffable of unpretentious things that by the simplicity reach the sublime".
In July that year, Manuel Bandeira invites Mário de Andrade to Rio de Janeiro to meet Ovalle. In his words, “You have to come to Rio only to meet Ovalle and to speak with him”.

Apart from being a composer, Ovalle also wrote poetry. According to Bandeira, “Ovalle the Poet was rather different to Ovalle the Musician[...]. The music of Ovalle was a sublimation of feeling and popular forms [...]. So is not his poetry, which has roots rather in the Bible, except for his love poetry of an extremely sophisticated nature."

Two days after the composer’s death, on the 11th of September, Carlos Drummond de Andrade publishes in the journal Correio da Manhã a chronicle entitled "At the Gate of Heaven", later collected in "Fala, amendoeira" (1957) in which he pays homage to Ovalle as “the man who from then on would survive almost as a myth”.

descricao: Pianist and composer, Vianna started to study piano at 8 years-old in his homeland, moving to Rio de Janeiro afterwards. In the 1920's, he begins to work as a composer and, at the request of Villa-Lobos, he composes a piece of music for the Modern Art Week. He was also conductor of the Paulistano Choir and professor at the National Institute of Music. Among his compositions, pieces for piano and voice stand out.

item.texto: He starts to study music (piano).
He moves to Rio de Janeiro in order to keep on studying at the National Institute of Music, where he was taught by Henrique Oswald.
At the request of Villa-Lobos, he composes a piece of music for the Modern Art Week.
Composes the piece Variações sobre um tema popular.
Travels to Europe to master his musical skills and returns to Brazil 3 years later.
He is named professor of piano at the National Institute of Music.
Composes Seresta para flauta e fagote.

descricao: He was a composer, flutist, saxophonist and arranger. Pixinguinha is one of the most prominent names in Brazilian music of all the times. Moreover, he was a heir of the best tradition of "choro"at the end of 19th century. He also consolidated and renewed his repertoire with classic songs as Carinhoso, Um a zero and Ainda me recordo.

item.texto: He lived with his family in a neighborhood called Catumbi, where went to the Professor Bernardes School at the Miguel Paiva street. His father, Alfredo Vianna, was an amateur flutist andwent often to the areas where people used to play "Choro". His father also used to received in his house some of the most famous musicians of that time such as Irineu de Almeida and Quincas Laranjeiras.

Together with his two brothers, Leo and Henrique, Pixinguinha received his first music lessons from Cesar Borges Leitão, who was an instrumentalist of bombardino and also fellow of Pixinguinha's father.

He won from his father a flute worth in 600 thousand "reis"(Brazilian currency at the time) imported from Europe. After that Pixinguinha started his classes woth Irineu de Almeida. In the same year, starts to record his first songs at Casa Falhaber.
Pixinguinha's brother took the violinist called China to present for the first time in a club in Rio de Janeiro, La Concha. The owner of this club used to pay for each concert 6 thousand "reis".
When he was 16 years-old joined the orchestra of the Rio Branco theatre. At the time, Pixinguinha was replacing the flutist Antonio Maria Passos.
