Inspired by texts written by the poet Manuel Bandeira, he records Música de Sobrevivência, with the same team who recorded is previous album.
In Brazl, BMG distributes 10 of the 15 albums Gismonti recorded for the Norwegian label ECM between 1977 and 1993.
Composes the soundtrack for the exhibition A revolta, by Franz Krajcberg.
Releases Zigzag, with Nando Carneiro and Zeca Assumpção.

The CD Meeting Point, recorded with the Lithunian State Symphony Orchestra, is released in Brazil. The album pays tribute to the composers Carlo Gesualdo (1560-1613) and Igor Stravisnki (1882-1971), in compositions that include Strawa no Sertão, Música para cordas, Frevo, A Pedrinha Cai, Eterna and Música de Sobrevivência.
Composes the soundtrack for the film Estorvo, directed by Ruy Guerra.
Composes the soundtrack for the film Gaigin II, directed by Tisuka Iamasaki.
Composes the soundtrack for the film Tempo de Paz, directed by Daniel Filho.
Composes the soundtrack for the film Chico Xavier, directed by Daniel Filho.

descricao: Son of a violinist of the Municipal Theatre of Rio de Janeiro's orchestra, Rio de Janeiro native from the neighborhood Santa Teresa, and pianist that at the age of 16 has already belonged to the bossa nova movement. Antônio Adolfo started to study music in his childhood and from the begining of 60's he started to attend different places in Rio de Janeiro where jazz and bossa nova were played. Travelled across Europe with Elis Regina and composed soundtracks for the cinema, theatre and television. In 1970, he won the V International Song Festival with the song BR3, composed with Tibério Gaspar and performed by Tony Tornado. He is the director, organizer and professor of the established by him Centro Musical Antônio Adolfo.

item.texto: Wilson Simonal's voice in the performance of Só Marina, created together with Tibério Gaspar, earns Antônio Adolfo a great success across the country.
He did a show in Songbook Café in Rio de Janeiro, together with Carlos Lyra. In the same year, he released the CD "Carnaval piano blues".
Released the CD “Finas misturas” that is a mixture of different Brazilian music styles with jazz.

descricao: Tavinho spent his childhood in Juiz de Fora and from an early age his father, mother and aunts accompanied the sound of the guitar, the cavaquinho and the mandolin. His mother moved with her children to Belo Horizonte in 1954. At age 14, Tavinho began working as a draftsman. He began his musical and artistic career composing film tracks.

PhD in composition from the University of New York. Effective member of the Brazilian Academy of Music. Her musical production went through different phases: timbre research, non-dodecaphonic serialism and intertextual procedures, all under literary influence. In most of her works the voice is present, spoken or sung in solo or chorus, conveying inarticulate sounds and poetic texts.

item.texto: Her training in composition was guided by Ernst Widmer in the Universidade Federal da Bahia, in Salvador, graduating with a bachelor degree in instrument.
She specializes in Novo Teatro Musical (New Musical Theatre) held at the School of Music in Cologne, Germany, under the direction of Mauricio Kagel.
She graduates with a master degree in composition at the State University of New York, Buffalo.
She gets a doctorate (PhD) in composition, also at the State University of New York, under the guidance of Lejaren Arthur Hiller.
Ilza perfoms her post-doctorate in music theory at Yale University, under the guidance of Dr. Janet Schmalfeldt.
She retires from Associate Professor post of the Department of Music of the Federal University of Paraiba, where she taught theoretical subjects in the Bachelor of Instrument and Composition.
Becomes member of the Brazilian Academy of Music occupying the chair N.º 27.

Teaches the new Graduate Program in Music of UFPB, also serving as a Chief Editor of scientific publication of this program, the journal "Claves". In this date she writes the Suíte Opara (Paisagens sonoras do médio São Francisco), for wind quintet.
Composes Memórias for flute, cello and piano.

descricao: Ronaldo Miranda started his career as music critic and he has intensified his work as a composer since 1977 when won the first prize at the Composition Contest to the II Bienal de Música Brasileira. On the following years, he has received several awards and the trophy Golfinho de Ouro (1981) in the state of Rio de Janeiro. In 2001, he was presented with Carlos Gomes Award for the best composer.

item.texto: Won the first prize at the Musica Composition Contest II Bienal de Música Brasileira Contemporânea, at Cecília Meireles Hall, on chamber music's category, with the piece Trajetória (Orlando Codá's lyrics).
He was selected to represent Brazil at the International Rostrum of Composers in Paris with the musical piece Trajetória.
He won the trophy Golfinho de Ouro of the Federal Government in Rio de Janeiro State.
The São Paulo Critics of Art Association (Associação de Críticos de Arte de São Paulo - APCA) considered his Variações sinfônicas as the best orchestral work of the year.
He participated in important international festivals like the World Music Days in Aarhus – Denmark  (1983) and the X Bienal de Música de Berlim (1985).
He received the title of Chevalier dans l´Ordre des Arts et des Lettres, granted by the Ministry of Culture in France.
He received the third prize on the Budapest Composition International Contest with Três momentos for cello. Writes Concertino para Piano e Orquestra de Cordas.

obras.titulo: Concertino para piano e orquestra de cordas

item.titulo: Concertino para piano e orquestra de cordas

item.texto: Três momentos – for cello and piano was released in March at the Spring Festival of the Hungarian capital.
He was awarded with the Bolsa Vitae to compose Dom Casmurro, an opera based on the Machado de Assis novel.
He participated on the festival Sonidos de las Américas – Brasil, at the Carnegie Hall in New York City.
Composes the Suíte festiva and, in the following year, Variações sérias.

item.titulo: Variações sérias sobre um tema de Anacleto de Medeiros

item.texto: Composes, by the Ministry of Culture request, the Sinfonia 2000 to commemorate the 500th anniversary from discovery of Brazil.
Receives the trophy Carlos Gomes from the Secretary of Culture of São Paulo State, as the best composer of the year.

He is one of the nine composers that have participated on the Amazônia Deslendada project sponsored by Apollon Foundation of Bremen creating music to three poems by Hermann Hesse, all colected in a musical piece titled Unterwegs.

obras.titulo: Concerto para quatro violões e orquestra

item.texto: He was at the premiere of his Concerto para quatro violões e orquestra at the Meyerhoff Hall in Baltimore during the First World Guitar Congress.

Premiere of Etius Melos, as a Suíte nº1 para violoncelo solo, of Johann Sebastian Bach, at Teatro Cultura Artística in São Paulo, also played in several Brazilian cities thereafter. Wrote Celebrare - uma abertura festiva to celebrate the 40th anniversary of Cecília Meireles Hall.

Composes the opera A Tempestade, based on a William Shakespeare play, requested by the Banda Sinfônica of State of São Paulo. The premiere was in September at Theatro São Pedro, São Paulo, conducted by Abel Rocha and with William Pereira as an artistic director, receiving the APCA award.

descricao: A composer, singer, pianist and professor at the University of São Paulo (USP), he studied piano at the Conservatory of São Vicente and refined his craft with Maestro João de Souza Lima. In 1967, he enrolled in USP's Languages programme and began to compose. He has recorded four albums and composed music for film and for the dance company O Corpo.

item.texto: Composes the score for Nilson Villas-Boas' short film "A mulher do atirador de facas", which wins the Kikito Award at the Gramado Film Festival under the category Original Music for a Short Film. He also receives the Noel Rosa Trophy Lei Sarney Award for Culture under the category for Best New Composer.

Composes the score for Grupo Corpo's production of "Nazareth", which receives the São Paulo Art Critics Association Award under the category Music for Dance. Launches the CD "José Miguel Wisnik", a highlight of which is the track "Estranho Jardim" (with Paulo Leminski and Adem Michiowicz).

Composes the score for Walter Salles' and Daniela Thomas' feature film "Terra estrangeira” (Foreign Land), as well as Teatro Oficina's production of Oswald de Andrade's play "Mistérios Gozozos", directed by Zé Celso Martinez Corrêa. Wins another São Paulo Art Critics Association Award under the category Music for Theatre.
Composes the score for "Parabelo" (with Tom Zé), a dance piece by Grupo Corpo.
On Gal Costa's album "Aquele frevo axé", distinguishes himself as a composer of the song "Assum branco", a reworking of "Assum preto" by Luiz Gonzaga and Humberto Teixeira.
Performs the song "DNA", written for his daughter, at the Festival of Brazilian Music (Globo network). Launches the CD "São Paulo Rio", a highlight of which is "Virtual" (with Alice Ruiz).
Composes the score for João Jardim and Walter Carvalho's feature film "Janela da alma", which is awarded a prize at the Ceará Film Festival.

Records the CD "Pérolas aos poucos", which includes his compositions Tempo sem tempo (with Jorge Mautner), Primavera, DNA (with Luciana Alves on vocals), Assum branco (with Caetano Veloso on vocals) and the title track Pérolas aos poucos (with Paulo Neves).

descricao: Composer, arranjer, cellist and luthier of unconventional instruments, Marco Antônio created the Uakti group. In UFBA (Federal University of Bahia) he had classes with Walter Smetak and Ernst Widmer. Along with Uakti group, he toured Europe, United States and Japan. Among his works stand out 5 tracks for the dance crew Grupo Corpo and 3 soundtracks for Brazilian movies.

item.texto: He moved to Salvador to study conducting at UFBA, where he kept contact with Walter Smetak and Ernst Widmer.

Returns to Belo Horizonte, where he joined the UFMG's (Federal University of Minas Gerais) Symphony Orchestra as a cellist. During this period he starts creating his first unconventional musical instruments.
Composes his Oferenda Musical, for string orchestra.
Creates the Uakti instrumental group.
Composes A Lenda.
Receives the Sharp Award for the best arranger and best instrumental group.
Composes the soundtrack for the Bach spectacle from the crew dance Grupo Corpo.
Receives the Multicultural Estadão Award.

descricao: Singer, composer and guitar player, he is descendant of explorer João Gonçalves da Costa, who founded city Vitória da Conquista. Xangai met the composer Elomar when he was 9 year old and became a kind of apprentice and friend. His work, with more than 100 pieces, shows the originality and typical elements of Brazilian northeast music.

item.texto: Born in Itapebi countryside, south of Bahia state, he moves with his family to Nanuque, in Minas Gerais, at age of 18.
This year he records his first album "Acontecivento", with songs like Forró de Surubim and Esta mata serenou, among others.
In a partnership with Elomar and the pianist Arthur Moreira Lima, he releases the album "Parceria Malunga", for Discos Marcus Pereira.
He releases the album "Qué que tu tem canário" and starts a partnership with Kuarup Discos Company.
In honor of his master and friend Elomar, releases the album "Xangai canta cantigas, incelenças, puluxias e tiranas de Elomar" for Kuarup Discos.
In a partnership with the great Brazilian composer and musician Renato Teixeira, he releases the CD "Aguaraterra".
Xangai is invited to participate of album released in celebration of 100th anniversary of club Esporte Clube Vitória.
He participates in the last career shows of singer Waldick Soriano, performing in several cities around Brazil.
Xangai debuts on Brazilian TV in a soap opera named Velho Chico.

descricao: Djavan was born in Alagoas and as soon as he gets to Rio de Janeiro, he is hired by Globo TV to perform other composers'songs for soap operas' soundtraks. His peculiar way of singing and playing the guitar called the attention of both critics and public. He incorporated several influences to his songwriting and became renowned as national and international singer and songwriter, having been nominated for the Latin Grammy.

item.texto: He records his first LP album.
He launches his album Alumbramento, which includes one of his greatest hits, the song Meu bem querer.
He is nominated by the Associação Paulista de Críticos de Arte (São Paulo Association of Art Critics) as Best Composer.
He records the LP Seduzir.
He makes his debut in the international market with the album Luz, recorded in Los Angeles, featuring Stevie Wonder and other American musicians, launched by CBS/Sony Music.
In the United States, he launches a compilation album of Lilás and Luz.
He records the LP Não é azul mas é mar, which is launched in the international market with three tracks in English and the title Bird of Paradise.
The song Oceano, which is the name of his new record, is included in the soundtrack of the soap opera Top Model, boosting his popularity.
He launches his Songbook by Lumiar.
He launches the CD Bicho solto.
He launches the DVD Djavan live.
He records the CD Milagreiro, with only original songs and the participation of his kids as partners in a few songs and also other musicians.
He creates his own record label, Luanda Records, and launches the CD Vaidade.
He is nominated for the Latin Grammy for his CD Vaidade.
He records the CD Na pista, etc.
He launches the CD Ária, in which he performs songs by other composers.
He launches the DVD Ária, recorded at Palácio das Artes (Palace of Arts) in Belo Horizonte.

descricao: Singer, songwriter and instrumentalist, Raimundo Fagner Candido Lopes came to prominence in the Brazilian music scene in the 1970s. His breakthrough happened in the Youth Music Festival at the University of Brasilia in 1971, which earned him awards of best songwriter, interpreter and arrangement. Since then, his songs began to be recorded by great names of MPB, including Elis Regina and Simonal. In 1975 he was named Singer of the Year, and his song Mucuripe was recorded by Roberto Carlos. In the 1980s, when already internationally renowned, he produced and wrote the LP Traduzir-se, featuring important artists from Latin America, including Mercedes Sosa. At the time, he was honored with a television miniseries. In addition to the extensive artistic and music production, Fagner has also been dedicated himself to social work and, in 2000, created the Raimundo Fagner Social Foundation, whose work has been awarded by institutions such as the Brazilian Ministry of Culture and UNICEF.

item.texto: Elis Regina records Mucuripe, which had become a big hit, thus spreadong Faner's name throught the country. In the same year, records the LP "Manera Frufru Manera" with the songs Mito 1 and Mucuripe (both featuring Belchior); Como se fosse (with Capinan); Canteiros (with lyrics based on a poem of Cecília Meirelles); Sina and Manera Frufru Manera (both featuring Ricardo Bezerra), among others.

His composition Cavalo ferro was record on the album "Meu corpo, minha embalagem, tudo gasto na viagem", which brought together the musical group Pessoal do Ceará, composed by Ednardo, Rodger Rogério, Teti and Cirino.

Releases his second album, "Ave noturna", with the songs Fracassos, wich would be recorded later with Cauby Peixoto, Ave noturna, in collaboration with Cacá Diégues (for the movie "Joana, a francesa") and Astro vagabundo, in collaboration with Fausto Nilo.

Releases the LP "Raimundo Fagner", which ranges between different rythms and styles such as the rock of ABC, the romanticism of Conflito and Asa partida (this last one in collaboration with Abel Silva), and a song of northeastern characteristics, the Matinada.

Releases the album "Orós", with arrangements and production by Hermeto Pascoal. The song Cebola cortada becomes a huge hit, alongside Orós. The following year releases Quem viver chorará, dedicated to his parents José Fares and Dona Francisca.

Releases the LP "Beleza". His song Noturno achieves great success and becomes the opening theme of the soap opera "Coração alado", on TV Globo. The album release was performed with great success in a performance at the Teatro João Caetano, in Rio de Janeiro.

The LP "Traduzir-se" was released simultaneously in Brazil and Spain. The album, dedicated to Glauber Rocha, featured various Latin artists such as Mercedes Sosa, Joan Manuel Serrat and Camaron de La Isla. One of the most played songs was Fanatismo, with Fagner's music to Florbela Espanca's poem.
Releases the  LP "Luis Gonzaga e Fagner". Four years later, due to the success of this work, releases the LP "Gonzagão e Fagner 2".

He releases his last album for CBS, with arrangements by Lincoln Olivetti, Wagner Tiso and Reinaldo Arias. In this work, Fagner presents a great variety of rhytms: the northeast sound of Dona dos teu olhos, by Humberto Teixeira, the romanticism of Sobre a terra and the pop rock of Contra-mão, in collaboration with Belchior.

Debuts on RCA with the album "Fagner" in which he interprets Dona da minha cabeça, by Geraldo Azevedo and Fausto Nilo. On the same album made into music the poems Os amantes, by Afonso Romano de Sant'Anna and Rainha da vida, by Ferreira Gullar.
Alongside with cearense actress Florinda Bolkan, takes part as a leading man in the miniseries "A Rainha da Vida", on TV Manchete, being also responsible for the soundtrack of the story.
Releases one of his greatest success, the song Borbulhas de amor.

Going back to his northeastern roots, Fagner records songs such as Lembrança de um beijo and Cavaleiro da noite. The following year he goes back to recording in collaboration with Fausto Nilo, Petrúcio Maia, Clodô and Nonato Luiz.

Releases a CD recorded live at the Centro Cultural Dragão do Mar, in Fortaleza, Ceará.This CD features the song Canteiros, whose lyrics are a poetry by Cecília Meirelles that for 20 years had been forbidden from being used, and then released after a deal with the poet's family. The CD, which sold about half a million copies, became one of the artist's biggest success.
The record label BMG rleases the first double CD "Gonzagão e Fagner", reproducing both previous LP's with the two artists.

Releases the CD "Raimundo Fagner", bringing new songs in collaboration with Fausto Nilo, such as O vinho and Jardim dos animais. The CD features a guest appearance by Zeca Baleiro on the track Tua boca, and both also sign Tempestade and Outra face.
Releases the CD "Raimundo Fagner e Zeca Baleiro", featuring Balada de agosto, Um real de amor, Palavras e silêncios and Dezembros, among others.
Releases the song Uma canção no rádio, in collaboration with Zeca Baleiro.
Releases the album "Fagner & Zé Ramalho ao vivo".

descricao: Flavio began his musical education at the age of 15 with the accordion as his first instrument, and soon after, began his piano studies in Belo Horizonte. He was revealed in the 70s by the Clube da Esquina movement, along with names like Milton Nascimento, Beto Guedes and Lô Borges. Created the musical group 14 Bis, in which remained until the end of the 80s, when he left to start a solo career. Among his pieces are hits like Todo Azul do Mar, Linda Juventude and Espanhola, this last one in a partnership with Guarabyra from duo Sá and Guarabyra.

item.texto: Participates in the musical group O Terço, in which would stay until 1976. Releases the disc Criaturas da Noite.
Participates in the creation of the 14 Bis group, which will achieve great success in the 80s. Release the LP 14 Bis.
With the same group, releases the LP Espelho das Águas.
Release the second LP of the group, 14 Bis II.
In a partnership with Guarabyra, from duo Sá and Guarabyra, composes Espanhola, a great success of the years 1986 and 1987.

In a partnership with Renato Russo, composer and singer of Legião Urbana band, composes Mais Uma Vez. This music was originally recorded this year by the group 14 Bis and will be recorded in a new version in 2003 by Renato Russo.
Nine years after he started his solo career, Flavio releases Trem Azul, by EMI/Odeon.
Releases the great hit Linda Juventude, by Som Livre, in CD and DVD.

descricao: Composer, violist and conductor, he is a researcher and professor of orchestral conducting at UFRJ (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro). He studied with Guerra-Peixe, Paulina d’Ambrosio, Carlos Alberto Pinto Fonseca and Santino Parpinelli, improving his knowledge in Florence. As a composer, he has been significantly succesful and his music is always present in concert programs, in Brazil and abroad.

item.texto: Composes Cantata de natal.
Assumes the coordinator role of Funarte's Orchestras Project where he remains until 1985.
Composes 6 Duetos para violoncelo.
Composes Bifonia n.3 for two clarinets, dedicated to Magistro Josepho Carolo Castrensi. Receives the Honorary Citizen title of Rio de Janeiro State.
Appointed to the Brazilian Academy of Music, Chair n° 14.
Writes the Cantata to celebrate the resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ.

obras.titulo: Cantata para festejar a ressurreição de Nosso Senhor Jesus Cristo

descricao: Son of samba composer Oswaldo Melodia and raised on Morro de São Carlos. He created a music band called Os Instantâneos when he was still a teenager along with Manoel, Nazareno and Mizinho, playing hits of Jovem Guarda and Bossa Nova movements. The experience at Estácio (samba school) along with the sounds of his youth resulted in a combination that give Melodia a unique composing style.

item.texto: Luiz Melodia reaches success with song Pérola negra recorded by Gal Costa and Estácio, Holly Estácio sung by Maria Bethânia.
Releases LP Pintando o sete with one of his biggest hits Codinome Beija-flor, written along with Cazuza, Ezequiel Neves and Reinaldo Arias.
Releases CD "Retrato do artista quando coisa". It was produced by the guitar player Perinho Santana, with strings and brass arrangements.
Releases CD "Zerima" during a concert at Teatro Rival BR, in Rio de Janeiro, its 14th solo album (Som Livre record label).

Wins the Brazilian Popular Music Award on the category "MPB - Popular Song- Best Singer" for "Zerima". Go on tour around Belo Horizonte, Porto Alegre, São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro to release "Zerima".

descricao: Born in Montes Claros, Minas Gerais, Beto Guedes is the youngest in a family of eight children. Composer and multi-instrumentalist, in a career of over 30 years he has recorded 12 albums and released 2 DVDs, as well as multiple appearances in other artists' works and notable groups, such as Clube da Esquina.

item.texto: Participates in the 5th International Song Festival with the composition Feira Moderna, in a partnership with Fernando Brant.
Releases his first LP A Página do Relâmpago Elétrico, with a great success in sales.
His new record Amor de Índio has the biggest success in his career as the tittle-track.
Releases his LP Alma de Borracha by Odeon, getting his first gold record with iver 200 thousand copies sold.
His LP's were released in CD format by EMI.
Release of his first DVD, "50 years live".
The composer's second DVD is recorded, "Outros clássicos", with lesser-known compositions.

descricao: Pianist, composer and musicologist, he studied with Souza Lima, Artur Hartmann and perfected his talent with Olivier Messiaen, in Paris. His work has more than 160 compositions. He is a member of the Brazilian Academy of Music and holds 10 prizes as a performer and 16 awards has a composer. He has performed more than 72 recordings, focused on Liszt's work and on his own compositions.

item.texto: After a long period perfecting his talent in Europe (France and Germany), where he studied piano and composition with notorious names such as Olivier Messiaen, Lucette Descaves and Carl Seemann, he returns to Brazil and resumes the task to disseminate classical music.
Receives the Arthur Honneger International Composition Award.
He is awarded with the Grand Prix International (Fondation de France), for his composition Trilogia opus 137.
Takes place the "Festival Amaral Vieira - o compositor e sua obra", in São Paulo. In the event, there were 14 concerts and 157 pieces by Vieira were performed.
He receives the Lizst Award in recognition of his studies, recordings and recitals of Franz Lizst music.

obras.titulo: Te Deum in stilo barocco op.213

item.texto: He is elected President of the Brazilian Musicological Society, until 1995.
He becomes President of the Brazilian Society of Contemporary Music, serving a four-year mandate.
Amaral Vieira performs his 5th tour in Japan with 17 concerts. He returns to Japan in 2008 for his 8th tour, achieving the milestone of 250 concerts in that country in more than 200 cities.
Amaral Vieira is awarded the 2008 Golden Laurel Award, granted by Delian Society, for his entire work. This was the first time that the award was granted to a Brazilian composer.

descricao: Award-winning Brazilian composer and member of the Brazilian Academy of Music, he was an apprentice of Ernst Widmer. Naturally influenced by the rhythms of his homeland, his work is a mix of the European formality and his cultural roots, resulting in an universal discourse. He was a professor and director of the Music School at the Federal University of Bahia. His catalog has 106 works and 350 performances in more than 15 countries.

item.texto: Paulo starts his career as a professor at UFBA. Later he would be the director of the Music School in this University.
Composes the Abertura Halley op.22, for symphonic orchestra.
Writes his work Ponteio para piano solo op. 35
In honor of the Federal University of Bahia, he composes the Canção da UFBA, with lyrics by José Carlos Capinam.
Composes the Serenata Ayó for symphonic orchestra.

obras.titulo: Serenata Ayó para orquestra sinfônica op. 76

item.texto: His work Yêlelá Twendê for 2 sopranos, bass, PC and orchestra is awarded by the Secretaria de Cultura da Bahia and it is recorded.

Won first place in the National Composition Award of FUNARTE (Prêmio Nacional de Composição da FUNARTE), gaining the opportunity to have his work performed at the opening of the 21st Brazilian Contemporary Music Biennial (XXI Bienal de Música Brasileira Contemporânea).

descricao: Cazuza was a singer, composer and poet. In the 80s, he turned into music the concerns of his generation in a partnership with Frejat and the band Barão Vermelho. In 1985, he released the solo album "Exagerado". In 1989 he admitted being HIV Positive and kept composing classics. The American Magazine "Rolling Stone" considers him one of the hundred greatest Brazilian musicians.

item.texto: He is introduced by Léo Jaime to the group Barão Vermelho, in which was integrated as the lead singer. As composer, he starts his partnership with Frejat.
The first album of the group Barão Vermelho is released. Caetano Veloso has included in his show one of Cazuza and Frejat's compositions, drawing attention to the group.
The fourth LP "Maior abandonado", named after one of his compositions with Frejat, is released. In six months, it reached the 100,000 copies sold milestone.
The single composed for the movie Bete Balanço is recorded. In this movie, Cazuza also performed as an actor, achieving a huge success.
The group Barão Vermelho performs in the first edition of the Rock in Rio.
Cazuza leaves the Barão Vermelho in order to pursue a solo career.
His solo album "Exagerado" is released. Remarkably, the tracks are more influenced by the MPB. It is also the beginning of partnerships with other composers.
In collaboration with Gilberto Gil, Cazuza composes the theme song of the movie "Um trem para as estrelas", directed by Cacá Diegues. In this movie he also performs as an actor.
Together with Chico Buarque, Cazuza is awarded the Best Lyricist of the MPB.
He is awarded with the prize Sharp in two categories: Best Pop-Rock Singer and Best Pop- Rock Song.
His third LP "Ideologia" sells 500,000 copies, definitely establishing him as a renowned artist.
His last LP "Burguesia" is recorded as a double album.
The Songbook "Cazuza" is released shortly after his demise.
Directed by Sandra Werneck and Walter Carvalho and based on Cazuza's biography written by his mother, Lucinha Araújo, the movie "Cazuza - Eu preciso dizer que te amo" begins shooting.
A tape record of his show at the Theater Ipanema, "Só se for a dois", is transformed into the album "Cazuza - o poeta está vivo".

descricao: He received his nickname due his amazing ability to improvise pagodes (a kind of samba) at famous Tia Doca house, in Madureira. In the carnival group "Cacique de Ramos" he met Arlindo Cruz, who would be his partner in several songs. Zeca started his professional career when recorded Camarão que dorme a onda leva, in a partnership with Arlindo Cruz.

item.texto: He participates in the recording of album "Raça brasileira", which brought together four big talents of Brazilian samba: Jovelina Pérola Negra, Pedrinho da Flor, Elaine Machado and Mauro Diniz. The samba Castelo de cera is one of tracks of the CD "Seja sambista também", by the group Fundo de Quintal.
His samba Camarão que dorme a onda leva, composed together with Arlindo Cruz and Beto sem Braço, is recorded by the famous singer Beth Carvalho. Zeca becomes knowed nationally.

obras.titulo: Camarão que dorme a onda leva

item.texto: His first album “Zeca Pagodinho” is released with sambas Quando eu contar (Serginho Meriti and Beto Sem Braço), Coração em desalinho (Monarco and Ratinho) and SPC (Zeca Pagodinho and Arlindo Cruz), among others.
Releases the LP "Jeito moleque" in which he plays his songs Se tivesse dó (composed with Nélson Rufino) and Chamego de pai (with Beto Sem Braço), among other compositions.
He wins Prêmio TIM 2004 prize in the category "Best Samba Singer".

descricao: Director of the Sala Cecília Meireles and member of the Brazilian Music Academy, Ripper is one of the most applauded Brazilian composers. His opera production is remarkable, highlighting his national theme operas such as Domitila and Piedade. The composer's official website is http://www.joaoripper.com.br

item.texto: Ripper travels to the USA to proceed with his doctoral studies in the Catholic University of America, in Washington D.C., under the orientation of the violinist and composer Helmut Braunlich (composition) and the musicologist Emma Garmendia (Latin America music).
Received the first award in the contest Concurso de Composição Cidade do Rio de Janeiro.

He returned to Brazil after a period dedicated to study aboard and reassumes his position as a professor in the Escola de Música da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), teaching composition, analysis, Schenker analysis and harmony. Ripper was also the coordinator of the post-graduation in 1998, and director of this institution from 1999 to 2003.
Receives the Associação Paulista dos Críticos de Arte (APCA) award for his opera Domitilia, based in the love letters of Dom Pedro I and the Marquesa de Santos.
From this year to 2005, Ripper was musical director and titular regent of the Orquestra de Câmara do Pantanal, in Mato Grosso do Sul.
Composes the Cantata a Céu Aberto, about Manoel de Barros poems and dedicated to Ignez Correa da Costa, in memoriam.
Ripper was nominated director of the Sala Cecília Meireles, position he occupies until nowadays.
Composes Metamorphosis para violino e piano, dedicated to Caterine Colp.

descricao: Graduated in Composition and Conducting and PhD in Composition at the Federal University of Bahia (UFBA), he was a disciple of Ernst Widmer and Jamary Oliveira. Furthermore he was a composer and professor at the UFBA School of Music, where he was also the director and served as a violist of OSUFBA. As a composer, he received several national and international awards. His works, written for different ensembles, have been performed in Brazil and in several countries such as Germany, Poland, Denmark, Italy and US.

item.texto: He graduated in Composition and Regency at UFBA.
Wins the third place in the 3rd Heitor Villa-Lobos National Composition Contest, by the Symphony Orchestra of Brasilia.
Gets first place in the 4th National Composition Contest in the UFBA School of Music.
Participates as a violist of the Bahia Ensemble group for seven consecutive years (until 1997).
Composes Alabalaxé, for orchestra.
Composes his piece Rondando (for guitar) and Obstinação (for piano).
Completes his doctorate in composition at the Federal University of Bahia.
Holds the position of principal of the School of Music at UFBA, until following year.
Composes his piece Batuque no jazz do xaxaxá.

He awarded the International Prize of Composition Klang der Welt - Drei Lateinamerikanische Länder, for his work Matizes Circulares (flute, clarinet, violin and cello), at Deutsche Oper Berlin, Germany.
Composes Geometrias flutuantes, for orchestra.
Receives the Funarte Classical Composition award this year.
Receives the Funarte Classical Composition Award 2012.

descricao: Compositor, pianista, arranjador, autor teatral e ator. Estudou na Escola de Música da UFRJ e na Escola de Música Villa-Lobos. Participou como compositor e regente de diversos festivais de música contemporânea no Brasil e no exterior. É autor de óperas,musicais, música de câmara e música eletroacústica. Recebeu diversos prêmios (Mambembe, Shell e Coca-Cola).

He participated of Caetano Veloso's band in the album "Estrangeiro", when his song Meia Lua Inteira achieved a great succes in Brazil and abroad. In the 1990's he stood out nationally and internationally as a leader of Timbalada group. Some time later Timbalada's success, Carlinhos began his solo career releasing the album "Alfagamabetizado".

item.texto: He participates in the Acordes Verdes band and becomes one of the most respected percussionists of Bahia. He is one of the creators of samba-raggae.
His song Visão de Cíclope, composed in a partnership with Luiz Caldas and Jeferson, became one of the most played hits in Salvador radios.
He takes part of Caetano Veloso's band in the album "Estrangeiro". His song Meia Lua Inteira, one of the tracks on the disc, was a great hit in Brazil.
Creates Timbalada, a group formed with more than 100 percussionists and singers, called "timbaleiros", most of them youth from Candeal neighborhood, where Carlinhos was born.
Paralamas do Sucesso band and Djavan recorded Uma Brasileira, a Brown partnership with Herbert Viana, leader of Paralamas group.

The album “Mineral”, released by Timbalada group, brings his composition Água mineral, a big hit of this year. He also releases his first solo album "Alfagamabetizado" and the song A namorada stands out. The album entered the list of the book "1001 Albums to hear before you die".
His second solo album "Omelete Man" is released, in which he duets with Marisa Monte singing Busy Man.
Together with Marisa Monte and Arnaldo Antunes, he creates the Tribalistas project. As a result, the CD and DVD with songs such as Já Sei Namorar and Velha Infância become a great success.

descricao: Began her career in Porto Alegre singing in restaurants and bars. In the late 1980's moved to Rio de Janeiro and, in 1992, she launched the album Senhas, from which song Mentiras was included on the soap opera soundtrack for Renascer (TV Globo), projecting her nationally. In 2004 she launched her album Adriana Partimpim, entirely dedicated to children.

item.texto: Recorded her first album, Enguiço.
She recorded the album A fabrica do poema, critically acclaimed, in which 2 songs stand out: Cariocas and Metade.

Launched the album Público, recorded live in the homonymous show held in Canecão, Rio de Janeiro, in which she presented herself with only her classic guitar. This very critically acclaimed album was contemplated with the Golden Record.

Recorded the album Cantada with participation of Daniel Jobim and group Los Hermanos, Bossacucanova e Moreno + 2. Still in 2002, she performed at DirectTV and Canecão, with her release show album, which earned her another Golden Record.

Unde the heteronym Adriana Partimpim, an alias the singer has used as a child, she launched her homonymous album dedicated to children. This album was awarded a Golden Record in Brazil and a Platinum Record in Portugal. It also earned the singer the prize Faz Diferença from the newspaper O Globo.

Launched Partimpim Dois. The album was included in the list Os Melhores Discos de 2009 from newspaper O Globo, published in the end of 2009, signed by music critics Antonio Carlos Miguel, Bernardo Araújo, João Pimentel, Leonardo Lichote and Tom Leão.
She launched the album O micróbio do samba which stands out the song Eu vivo a sorrir, of her authorship.

descricao: Singer and composer from Salvador, Bahia. She started singing in pubs of Salvador when she was 16 years old, including songs by Luis Gonzaga, Ari Barroso, Caetano Veloso, Gilberto Gil and Chico Buarque in her shows. In 1990's achieved great success singing a new genre, Axé Music. In 1993 Daniela begins her international career performing in USA.

item.texto: In July, Daniela Mercury performs to more than 20,000 people at Modern Art Museum of São Paulo (Masp). The hit O canto da cidade (composed by Daniela in a partnership with Tote Gira) is released this year and achieves great popularity.
The album "Arroz com feijão" is released, with songs such as À primeira vista.
Daniela is the only Brazilian artist invited by Ennio Morricone to take part in his album featuring famous soundtracks for movies such as "Cinema Paradiso" and "Os intocáveis".

nome_completo: Brandão, Francisco de Assis França Caldas
descricao: Chico Science is one of the most important artists from Manguebeat movement. His career was prematurely cut short by a car accident. Chico released two albums, "Da lama ao caos" and "Afrociberdelia", both included between 100 Best Brazilian Music Albums by Rolling Stone magazine. In 2008, he was classified in 16th place in the category of Best Artists of Brazilian Music.

item.texto: He joined Legião Hip Hop, one of the most important street dance groups in Recife.
Created, in Olinda, the group Chico Science e Nação Zumbi.
In a short tour in São Paulo and Belo Horizonte, he drew media attention.

descricao: In the begining of his career he joined group Farofa Carioca, which blended different genres such as choro, samba, xote, hip hop and reggae. In 2001 debuts as an artist in the movie "Cidade de Deus”, whose closing song is his own. In 2010 he was very well ranked by Rolling Stone magazine.

item.texto: Release of the first album by group Farofa Carioca, "Moro no Brasil", which made possible the future Jorge solo carrer that would start from 2001.
Seu Jorge releases his first solo CD “Samba esporte fino”. His song Carolina becomes a big hit.
One of the big hits this year is Mina do condomínio, composed in a partnership with Pretinho da Serrinha, Gabriel Moura and Pierre Aderne.

descricao: Professor at Federal University of Paraíba since 2006, José Orlando Alves has a master's degree from UFRJ and concluded his PhD at UNICAMP. Among his prizes, he received an Honorable Mention in the Camargo Guarnieri National Composition Competition and won the first place in the 7th National Music Contest of IBEU (Instituto Brasil - Estados Unidos).

item.texto: He graduated in Music Composition at UFRJ with his Cantata para coro e orquestra, under the guidance of Pauxy-Gentil Nunes.
Under the guidance of Marisa Resende, José Orlando obtains the master's degree from UFRJ. In his dissertation, he researched the application of Set Theory in musical composition.
José Orlando wins the 1st place in the 7th National Music Contest of IBEU (Instituto Brasil - Estados Unidos), with Quantum, for winds quintet.

At UNICAMP, he concluded his PhD under the guidance of Jônatas Manzolli with the thesis "Invariância e Disposições Texturais: from the compositional planning until the reflection about the creative process".

obras.titulo: Inserções III para trombone e piano

item.titulo: Inserções III para trombone e piano

item.texto: He began his activities as an adjunct professor at the Federal University of Paraíba. In the same year, he was finalist of the 8th National Music Contest of IBEU (Instituto Brasil - Estados Unidos).
He obtains the 1st place in the category String Orchestra of the Prize FUNARTE of Classical Composition.

descricao: Born in Capão Redondo, neighborhood on the outskirts of São Paulo and source of inspiration for the lyrics of his compositions. He participated as vocalist of Racionais MC´s group, formed in 1988 and integrated by rappers Ice Blue (Paulo Eduardo Salvador), Edi Rock (Edivaldo Pereira Alves) and KL Jay (Kleber Geraldo Lelis Simões).

item.texto: Together with Racionais MC's group, he recorded his first album "Holocausto Urbano".
He records “Sobreviventes no Inferno”, album that sold more than one million copies.
Release of his first live album, "Racionais MC's Live".
He is classified by Rolling Stone Magazine taking the 28th place among 100 biggest Brazilian music artists this year.

nome_completo: Cady, Ivete Maria Dias de Sangalo
descricao: Singer, composer and instrumentalist. She achieved great success when was a singer of Banda Eva group. In her solo career she sold more than 15 million copies, one of the biggest sales in Brazil. Ivete is also an international awarded artist and knowed by her deep voice.

item.texto: Ivete starts his career in Salvador and receives the Caymmi Trophy for Debut Singer category.
Joins the group Banda Eva, with which she records six albums.
Releases her solo album "Ivete Sangalo" and achieves great success selling over 100,000 copies. Receives her first Golden Disc. The song Se eu não te amasse tanto assim becames a big hit in Brazil.

Ivete reaches the mark of 607,000 DVDs sold and becomes a worldwide sales record with "Multishow ao vivo: Ivete no Maracanã". She goes to Europe to perform in Portugal, Spain, Germany and Italy, besides making concerts in USA and countries of Latin America.

item.titulo: Vejo o Sol e a Lua

descricao: Singer, songwriter and instrumentalist. Son of musicians, he started his career in 1989 when created, alongside his brother and cousin, the band "Só pra contrariar", which became very succesfull in a short period of time. His international career also begun with the band. After publishing 7 albums with the group, he launches his solo career with the album "É por amor".

item.texto: Alexandre Pires created the band "Só pra contrariar", in tribute to the song recorded by group Fundo de Quintal.
The album “Só Pra Contrariar", by the band of the same name, launches the hit A barata, composed by Alexandre Pires.

In October 2nd, Alexandre Pires performed Garota de Ipanema (by Tom Jobim and Vinicius de Moraes) in the White House, for the President of the USA, George W. Bush, in an event that brings together Latin artists.

descricao: Valesca dos Santos began as a vocalist of the band Gaiola das Popozudas in 2000. With the release of the song Agora sou solteira, in 2007, she achieved national popularity. In 2011, the group travels in a international tour performing in United States and Europe. Back to Brazil, Valesca starts her solo career with the big hit Beijinho no Ombro.

When he was 10 years old, his father gives him an accordion. The gift has encouraged him to sing and at the age of 12 he formed a band called Guri. From 1994 his career took off and in 1997 he joins the band Tradição as a lead singer. Its biggest success are Barquinho, O caldeirão, Pra sempre minha vida e Eu quero você, all written by himself.

item.texto: Teló joins the band Tradição, as the lead vocals, in which he would remain until 2008.
He releases his first solo album "Balada Sertaneja".

Teló releases his second album "Na Balada". In the same year, he receives a golden disc for selling 40 thousand copies of the album "Michel Teló ao vivo" and releases the song Ai se eu te pego, which would become a international hit with the higher number of views in YouTube.
He wins 2 from the 7 categories of Billboard Latin Music Awards: Song of the Year and Pop Song of the Year, with the hit Ai se eu te pego.
He debuts, with the duo Chitãozinho e Xororó, the show "Bem Sertanejo" in Porto Alegre. Among the chosen songs were Evidências and Fio de cabelo.

descricao: Singer, composer and instrumentalist. At the age of 15, he created his first samba group named Sabe Demais, and later produced the first CD with the group. In 2002 he participated of TV show Fama, at TV Globo. With the group Exaltasamba, Thiaguinho recorded 10 CDs and 5 DVDs. In 2012 he starts his solo career as a singer and composer.

item.texto: The samba group Exaltasamba is created with names such as Péricles and Thiaguinho. Both singers would become popular in a short time.
Wins the Digital Music Award in the category "best-selling song" for Valeu, composed in a partnership with Rodriguinho.
Starts his solo career with a big show at Credicard Hall, in São Paulo, recording the live CD/DVD "Ousadia e Alegria".

descricao: Responsible for national hits Menina Má, Show das Poderosas and Meiga e Abusada, the last one was among the most requested Brazilian radio in 2013 and was included on the soundtrack of the soap opera "Amor à Vida", on TV Globo. Her first studio album was released in June 2013.

item.texto: Due to the huge success of the song Meiga e Abusada, she signed a millionaire contract with Warner Music label.
She obtained nominations and was the winner in the Prêmio Multishow award in categories "Best new artist" and "Best videoclip". Anitta also was elected as the Brazilian artist of the year bu iTunes.
It was released his first studio album "Anitta". Received triple gold and double platinum albums by Brazilian Association of Record Producers.
She was indicated to the Latin Grammy this year and also received the first prize from MTV European Music Awards in category "Best Brazilian Act".

descricao: He was born in a very poor neighborhood called Vila Progresso, in São Paulo. Before becomes a singer of funk genre, he worked in a famous street market in São Paulo.

item.texto: In December 18th his funk videoclip “Tá tranquilo, tá favorável” is launched in Youtube website, interpreted by himself. The video would be visualized for more than 12 million people in about 2 months.

descricao: Pero Vaz de Caminha, reporting to the Portuguese crown the arrival of the squad in Brazil, wrote: "On April 23rd, Frei Henrique celebrated the first outdoor mass. After the end of the mass, the Indians started playing the horn and began to jump and dance. And they did it well."

item.texto: Father Manuel da Nóbrega was the first Jesuit priest to celebrate a mass in Brazil on March 31st of this year, with a choir of laymen conducted by Father Leonardo Nunes. He went in a musical procession, as Nóbrega described: “the natives were astonished in such a way that they would later ask Father Navarro to sing to them just as he did in the procession”.

Jean de Lery, a Calvanist missionary, came to Brazil as a member of the France Antarctique Mission, led by Nicolas de Villegagnon, and he records six Tupinambás songs, one of which is “Canidé-iouue/ canidé-iouue heura-oueh” -  a worship song to Arara-canindé (Blue-and-yellow Macaw) – played in parties, anthropophagic rituals and on the eve of combats.

One of the earliest reports of the musical manifestations in Brazil is found in the book Duas Viagens ao Brasil, which gathers the memories of the German adventurer Hans Staden. In his account of being surrounded by the natives, he describes that "the women began to sing and, according to a given sound, [he] had to stomp [his] foot on the ground with rattles tied to it."

In the book Narrativa Epistolar de Uma Viagem Jesuítica (1847) by F. A. Varnhagen, Father Fernando Cardim describes what could have been the 1st known account of a non-religious manifestation in Brazil: “We had a dedicated Nativity Scene during Christmas, where we gathered a few times with good devotional music and brother Barnabé cheered us with his berimbau.

Gabriel Soares de Sousa, an important Portuguese chronicler of the sixteenth century, states in the “Tratado Descritivo do Brasil” (A Descriptive Treatise of Brazil), published in 1587, that the Tupinamba Indians of Rio de Janeiro were famous for being the best dancers and musicians among all the Tupi tribes of the Brazilian coast.

Marquise Ferreira donates the Fazenda de Santa Cruz (Imperial Farm of Santa Cruz), in the captaincy of Rio de Janeiro, to the Jesuit priests. Using music for the catechization of the natives, there the Jesuits developed musical activities with orchestra and choir composed of slaves and indigenous people.

With the expulsion of Jesuits from the domains of Portugal and its colonies in 1759, through the actions of Marquis of Pombal, the patrimony of the Companhia de Jesus and of Fazenda de Santa Cruz were reverted to the Crown. In the inventory of instruments of the farm was included, among others, three rabecas, a double bass, two recorders, a clarinet and a harpsichord.

nome: African music comes to Brazil with slaves
descricao: Since the middle of the 16th century, during the early colonization period, the Portuguese traded Africans to become slaves. At the beginning, around 1538, people came mainly from Guiné. According to priest José de Anchieta, Brazil had 57.000 inhabitants in 1585 - 14.000 were slaves brought from Africa: 10.000 in Pernambuco, 3.000 in Bahia and about a 1.000 in Rio.

item.texto: Typical manifestation of Pernambuco, dated 1711 (according to Gérard Béhague) the first mention of Maracatu, related with the antique coronation festivals of the black kings. Nowadays Maracatu happens during the Carnival, when groups organize themselves in "nations" of which one they include characters such as the King, the Queen, the Prince, the Princess, the Bridesmaids.

According to José Ramos Tinhorão "The definitive paganization of the ancient African batuques, ... not only permited one of the choreographic moments to be used, under the name of Lundu, but also gave to the batuque the name of Samba, when the Angolan element of the Umbigada prevailed. "

"Only a few black slaves gather and can be heard the cadenced beat of the hands; Is the signal of call and of a challenge to dance (...); It is mainly the hips that are shaken while the dancer snaps his tongues and fingers, accompanying a monotonous chant, the others circle around him and repeat the refrain."( Rugendas, in “Viagem pitoresca através do Brasil”).

In one of the poems of "Cartas Chilenas", published this year, Tomás Antonio Gonzaga points out a few different characteristics for the Batuque and the Lundu, which would have different forms: to the Lundu the author refers to as "hot", while Batuque would be "dispicable".

Alfredo Sarmento, in his work "Sertões D'Africa", reports the batuque as a lascivious dance of the Africans who, in a circle, went one by one to make movements and then performed a umbigada (semba) to the person chosen to replace him.  In Brazil, the batuque became a generic term applied to all the practices of black enslaved, including what was later called Lundu.
With the advent of phonograms, the lundu Isto é bom, by Xisto Bahia, was the first musical genre recorded in Brazil, interpreted by Bahiano.

Entering the so-called umbigada dances (related to "Semba" or "Masemba" from Angola), Jongo was brought to Brazil by black Bantu, kidnapped to be sold as slaves in the ancient kingdoms of Ndongo and Kongo, nowadays a large part of the Republic of Angola’s territory. As from 2005, Jongo became legally recognized as Brazilian intangible assets.

descricao: Since the establishment of the first diocese in Brazil, in Salvador (Bahia), the musical studies and new musical features begins, focused on the liturgy, which prevails until the late 18th century. At that period, the musical production was predominantly vocal and religious. Profane works or instrumental compositions were very rare.

item.texto: The gold exploration at state of Minas Gerais by a group of pioneers called Bandeirantes starts at the beginning of XVIII century. The city of Vila Rica – now called Ouro Preto – becomes the center of this activity. Through the whole century, the production intensifies and the opulence boosted musical activities and the arising of the first local composers, bands, corporations and groups.

The discovery in 1984 at Mogi das Cruzes (SP) of musical manuscripts brings to light 11 Portuguese-Brasilian pieces copied around 1730 – date of the type of paper used - one of the oldest sets of musical work known. Stands out Ex-Tratactu Sancti Augustini, by Frei Manoel Cardoso (1566 – 1650) and the piece Matais de Incêndios.

In Olinda, Pernambuco, was founded the Santa Cecilia's Corporation, the first one formed by professional musicians in the country. In Rio de Janeiro, 14 years later, would be founded the second corporation, and among the 32 founding members was the priest José Mauricio Nunes Garcia.

The appearance of a considerable number of musicians in several provinces (specially Minas Gerais state), the musical forms development such as masses, novenas, litany, magnificats, motets, Marian antiphons, Te Deums, hymns, offerings, solos, arias and triplets, and a growing musician professionalization indicate the flowering of sacred music in Colonial Brasil.

There are few records about life and work of one of the most eminent Minas Gerais composers, Lobo de Mesquita. Acting in the region of Serro and Diamantina in the second half of the eighteenth century, among his sacred works stands out the Missa para a quarta-feira de cinzas.

item.titulo: Missa para a quarta feira de cinzas

item.texto: The Museum of Music in Mariana, created from the establishment of the Archives of the Archdiocese of Mariana in 1965, is one of the most important Latin American religious manuscript music collection, and it has more than 2 thousand music sheets of Emerico Lobo de Mesquita and João de Deus de Castro Lobo, and many others.

​Created under the coordination of the Prof. Dr. Régis Duprat, the Inconfidência Museum Department of Music Studies is born with the donation of a manuscript collection gathered by Francisco Curt Lange when he worked on a music research during 1940 and 50's at several cities in Minas Gerais State. The collection has documents dated from 18th until 20th century.

nome: Military bands gain prominence in celebrations
descricao: Although the military bands were encouraged from arrival of the royal family in Brazil (1808), one of the first reports of these activities during 18th century reveals the bands participation in the birth celebrations of D. José, in 1762. In Rio de Janeiro there were military parades with musical instruments such as flutes, horns and atabales.

item.texto: One of the first records of military musical formations refers to their  performance at the celebrations of  the birth of Prince of Beira, Don Jose. At the procession through the streets of  Rio de Janeiro there were parades of military regiments playing marches using  instruments such as flutes, horns, timbales and drums.

Although a big incentive for military bands occurred from 1808 onwards, there are documents that show that as early as  the 18th century there were different musical formations of this genre all over Brazil, such as those created in the regiments from Recife and Olinda  by Governor Dom Tomás José de Melo.

According to official documents of the Province of Pernambuco, the musician Francisco Januário Tenório “enlisted (….) in the Regiment of Olinda, where he rehearsed a music genre which was part of the regiment, afterwards he organised another one for the Artillery Regiment”, confirming the presence of bands in Olinda at the end of the 18th century.

According to Rio de Janeiro Customs documentation from the end of the 18th century, there are records of the importation of diverse wind instruments coming from Lisbon mainly between 1796 and 1799. Among those instruments there were bugles, horns. Bassoons and trumpets. These were probably used for musical formations similar to the military bands of the city.

Even before the arrival of the Portuguese Royal Family in Brazil, boosting the Military Bands activity, on 13th May 1803 the Militia bands and the military front line bands of the city of Paraíba (now João Pessoa) shone at the birthday celebrations of D. João.
With the arrival of the Royal Family in Brazil in 1808, the activity of the military bands gained momentum. Together with D. João’s entourage, The Royal Brigades Band arrived  in the country.
On this date, according to a story told by Father Perereca, the expression “band” appeared for the first time in the Brazilian Administrative Legislation: “Regiment Music bands.

Debret described how since the arrival of Princess Leopoldina to Brazil there was a courtship with military bands in the port. After dinner and the appearance of the engaged couple on the balconies at her arrival event “all the troops that had gathered in the Largo do Palácio paraded in formation with their bands to salute the new Royal Brazilian Princess”.
There are reports that indicate that at the celebrations for the coronation and proclamation of D. João VI, the party that announced the coronation consisted of two military bands.

This year the French traveller Auguste Saint-Hilaire observed, at a dinner offered by the Governor of the province, the performance of a musical band in one of the Sao Paulo Regiments. On that occasion it paid homage to the Queen Carlota Joaquina.

During the Farrapos’ War the army band was imprisoned by the Farrapos soldiers who probably didn’t have a musical band. Soon after they were captured “they delighted the (musician) prisoners with full  freedom, who in turn showed deference to the  conquerors“ (REAL, 1980, p.231).

In this year in Rio de Janeiro, the Permanent Municipal Guards Corps already had a musical band that was highly praised in the advertisements for lessons held by the conductor Januário da Silva Arvellos.
There are records in the two battalions of the National Guard in São Paulo that there were at least 2 conductors and 50 musicians in the band, at this time.
Antonio Manoel do Espírito Santo, considered the greatest Brazilian composer of instrumental military music, composes Canção do Marinheiro.

nome: Theaters: music and the performing arts
descricao: Since the arrival of the Jesuits in the 16th century, religious plays were staged in the colony. From the 17th century there were few evidences on these activities. The great impulse for the performing arts occurred in 1770 in Minas Gerais, with the foundation of the Opera House of Vila Rica (nowadays, Ouro Preto), the oldest theater building in South America.

item.texto: Considered to be the first building constructed for theatrical purposes in Rio de Janeiro, Padre Bonaventura's Opera House was mentioned by a French sailor from the ship L'Arc en Ciel, docked in Rio de Janeiro from April 22 to May 10, 1748. He mentions life-size puppets, well made and richly decorated, as well as an “orchestra, good enough in violins".
The Vila Rica Opera House - nowadays the Municipal Theater of Ouro Preto, founded in 1769, is the oldest working theater in the Americas.

In order to endow the court of Rio de Janeiro with a space, as significant as the São Carlos Theater of Lisbon, the Real Theater of São João was built, where today is the Theater João Caetano. Its first performance was the drama "O Juramento dos Numes", with music written by Bernardo José de Souza Queiroz. It became the main opera stage at the start of the nineteenth century in Brazil.

After the fire of the Royal Theater of São João in 1824, the Imperial Theater of São Pedro of Alcântara was built, inaugurated on the birthday of Empress D. Leopoldina with the performance of the opera Tancredo by Rossini.

Consolidation of Music Theater (magazine theater, operetta, burlesque etc) as one of the main means of diffusion of popular music, while churches, aristocratic halls and music conservatories continue to be the source for more erudite music.

Foundation of The Imperial Academy of Music and National Opera (later named National Lyric Opera), subsidized by Dom Pedro II. Until 1863, 20 operas will be sung in Portuguese with a Brazilian theme. Among the composers: Carlos Gomes, Domingos José Ferreira, Elias Álvares Lobo, Henrique Alves de Mesquita and Martim Assu.

Symbol of the peak of the rubber cycle - Brazil being the largest producer in the world at that time -, the Amazonas Theater is one of the most important in the northern region of Brazil which hosts important opera seasons.

In the second half of the 19th century the artistic activity was very intense in Rio de Janeiro, even without a theater that would have an importance of the main city of the country. In 1903, Mayor Pereira Passos launched a project competition for the construction of the Municipal Theater, inaugurated six years later on the French revolution's day with a speech in French by Olavo Bilac.

Inauguration of The Municipal Theater of São Paulo, inspired by the Paris Opera. In 1922 it was the stage of the Modern Art Week, which introduced the modernism movement in the country. At the inauguration the overture O Guarany by Carlos Gomes was presented. The house currently supports activities of the São Paulo Symphony Orchestra, the Lyrical Choir and the Ballet of the City.

nome: Rio de Janeiro becomes the capital of the Portuguese court
descricao: On 7th of March, the Prince regent Dom João, his mother, Queen Maria I settled his court at Rio de Janeiro. The next day, they attend to a Mass with music by José Maurício Nunes Garcia, whose talent greatly impressed the Prince.

item.texto: D. João determines the transfer of the Cathedral to the N. Sra. do Carmo Church, next to the Imperial Palace, honoring it with the title of Royal Chapel, established to ensure the "greater decency and splendor of Divine Worship and Glory God's". The first chapel master, in charge of music for the liturgical feasts and royal celebrations, was Father José Maurício Nunes Garcia.

Marcos Portugal, renowned Portuguese composer, arrives in Rio de Janeiro after resisting for 3 years the appeals of D. João. He is received as a celebrity and appointed official composer of the court and master of music of His Royal Highnesses. One of his most successful operas in Europe - L'Oro non compra amore - is presented at the Teatro Regio on December 17th.

The Austrian musician Sigismund von Neukomm arrives in Brazil, who works until 1821 as a composer, teacher and promoter of European music. A great pianist, student of Haydn, he became music teacher of Prince D. Pedro, Princess Leopoldina, Infanta Isabel Maria and also composer Francisco Manuel da Silva.

The French Artistic Mission, led by Joachim Lebreton, comes to Brazil on the initiative of D. João VI with the purpose of founding the Academy of Fine Arts here. Among its members are Debret and Nicolas Taunay. It is due to its presence in the country the great impulse given to music and the plastic arts.

King D. João VI returns to Portugal and leaves Brazil under the regency of his son Pedro de Alcântara. The Brazilian musical environment is transformed after the departure of D. João VI. The music loses its main incentive.

descricao: Although the musical nationalism in Brazil occurs in the early 20th century, L'Amoreux, for piano and flute, by Sigismund Neukomm (1778-1858) was the first classic work written in the country inspired by a typically Brazilian popular genre: the modinha A Melancolia, by Joaquim Manoel da Câmara.

item.texto: Musical nationalism in Brazil begins to emerge, albeit in embryonic form, in the mid-nineteenth century. It sees composers starting to incorporate aspects such as rhythm from the music of African slaves and popular melodies into their work. One example of this is the publication of A Cayumba, by Carlos Gomes, which features rhythms based on Afro-Brazilian popular dances.

Brasílio Itiberê da Cunha publishes A Sertaneja, a work incorporating two traditional Brazilian songs, one of them the well-known Balaio, Meu Bem, Balaio. These works, however, are adapted to a habanera rhythm, and the piece’s overall texture remains typical of romanticism.
In Rio de Janeiro, Alberto Nepomuceno composes Batuque, joining the ever-growing ranks of those using elements of home-grown Brazilian music in their work.

Alexander Levy composes his Variations Sur un Theme Populaire Brèsilien. This follows a trend among composers of the period, particularly in São Paulo, who are beginning to use national motifs more frequently in their work.

Alexandre Levy composes two more works in the nationalist mould, Tango Brasileiro and Suíte Brasileira. The latter incorporates a samba into its fourth movement with the same melody as the song Balaio, Meu Bem, Balaio, used previously by Itiberê da Cunha in A Sertaneja.

Inspired by the songs of Brazilian folklore, Luiz Levy composes his Rapsódias Brasileiras. The first of these features the melody known in Brazil as Vem Cá Bitú, which dates back to the early nineteenth century, and is better known today through the popular song Cai, Cai, Balão.
At the beginning of the twentieth century, Francisco Braga composes his orchestral work Variações Sobre um Tema Brasileiro (Variations on a Brazilian Theme).

Influenced by Heitor Villa-Lobos, Lorenzo Fernandez develops an interest in the nationalist aesthetic and composes his Trio Brasileiro. The following year he writes a symphonic work based on three popular Brazilian melodies, and in 1929 he composes the ballet Imbapara, inspired by indigenous melodies collected by Edgar Roquette-Pinto in the Mato Grosso region of Brazil.

While the poet and music critic Mário de Andrade has attracted much attention with his interventions on the subject of nationalism, the composer Luciano Gallet is also making great strides in the field. Interested in Brazilian musical folklore, in 1924 he publishes the first two volumes of his Canções Populares Brasileiras, completed in 1926.

Mário de Andrade sets out on an expedition to collect and catalogue Brazilian folk melodies. In a journey similar to those undertaken by Bartók and Kodály in Hungary, he travels across various regions of Brazil, particularly on the Northeast and Minas Gerais.
Luciano Gallet composes his Turuna suite, which is considered to be the first work to fully embody the ideas of Brazilian musical nationalism.

Camargo Guarnieri composes Dança Brasileira and Canção Sertaneja. He first met Mario de Andrade two years earlier and became his student, writing works which would become points of reference for the nationalist movement.

Francisco Mignone moves to São Paulo, where he becomes acquinted with Mário de Andrade and the nationalist movement. This leads him to compose the Primeira Fantasia Brasileira for piano and orchestra.

Villa-Lobos, always one to do things his own way, begins to explore Brazilian material in his compositions towards the end of the 1920s. In 1930, he leaves his Choros series behind and begins the Bachianas Brasileiras, using elements of Baroque style inspired by J. S. Bach, alongside melodies based on traditional Brazilian songs and dances.

Camargo Guarnieri composes his Sonata No. 1 for cello and piano, which Mário de Andrade considers the first sonata essentially Brazilian. The composer uses fragments of the music of the Tupinambá people, documented by Jean de Léry in Rio de Janeiro in 1557.

Through the 1930s the nationalist movement gradually begins to diversify, moving away from its founding principles. The death of Mario de Andrade in 1945 accelerates its decline, its former adherents moving in new directions.

nome: Published the first book on music in Brazil
descricao: Is released the first book on music in Brazil, in Rio de Janeiro, the Imprensa Régia, "historical News of the life and works of Joseph Haydn", translation of the text of Joachim Le Breton, with the collaboration of Sigismund Neukomm.

item.texto: Until popularization of the record (c. 1920's), the score was the main vehicle of propagation of music in Brazil. In addition to the French Laforge, other pioneer music publishers were the Germans João Bartolomeu Klier and Carlos J. Wehrs, the English George Heaton, the Dutch Eduardo Rensburg, the Portuguese Rafael Coelho Machado and Arthur Napoleão and the Italian Isidoro Bevilacqua.

Frenchman Pierre Laforge is the first to establish himself regularly in Rio de Janeiro with a music press. During the almost two decades he was in charge of the business, he published works by José Maurício Nunes Garcia, Cândido Inácio da Silva, Gabriel Fernandes da Trindade, Francisco Manuel da Silva and Dom Pedro I.

nome: The first masked Carnival ball is held in Rio.
descricao: The majority of Emperor D. Pedro II starts the Second Empire. Societies are founded to promote concerts and balls, includind the first Carnival ball in 1836.

item.texto: Foundation of the dance society and carnival Democratic, in Rio de Janeiro.

First audition of the traditional carnival song "Zé Pereira", with lyrics by the actor Francisco Correia Vasques about the French band Desormes, refering the rhythm parades led by the Portuguese José Nogueira de Azevedo Paredes, popular since 1850.

Noisy sonic expressions based on percussive sonorous pulses and chants in different African languages coexist with genres with clearer harmonic-melodic forms: they are the many Brazilian carnivals, the "entrudos" and "afoxés" (specific kind of rhythms), the great societies, the parades and the "ranchos".

At the end of the nineteenth century a new genre of carnival music began to develop, which, like frevo, will only consolidate in the first half of the twentieth century: the marchinha and its slower rhythm variation, knowed as marcha-rancho.

Release of the maxixe (specific kind of rhythm)  Vem cá, mulata, by Archimedes de Oliveira, dedicated to the Democratics (dance and carnival society). The maxixe is very successful in the carnivals of the first decade of the 20th century. The main recordings are from Mário Pinheiro and Pepa Delgado, from the Casa Edison band (1905) and the duo Os Geraldos (1909).

Rancho Ameno Resedá is founded in Rio de Janeiro, one of the most important carnival ranches of all time. These groups were very popular carnival gatherings in the first decades of the twentieth century and their parade structure would be the basis for future samba schools.

Samba artists from the Estácio de Sá neighborhood, among them Ismael Silva, created the group "Deixa Falar", which soon became the Estácio de Sá Samba School, the first in Brazil. The term "samba school" is due to the fact that the rehearsals happened next to the Normal School.

nome: The Imperial Conservatory of Music is founded
descricao: Francisco Manuel da Silva, sponsored by Imperial Government, founds the Conservatory of Music of Rio de Janeiro in 1841. The activities would only begin in 1848, with six teachers, in a space that nowadays houses the National Archive.

item.texto: The Conservatory leaves its first location and begins his activities in the building of the Imperial Academy of Fine Arts. After the proclamation of the Republic, the Conservatory will be reformed and reopened, becoming the National Institute of Music, with Leopoldo Miguez as its director.

descricao: Musical education was institutionalized by Decree 1331 under the government of Emperor Dom Pedro II. Initially restricted to the capital Rio de Janeiro, it soon reached other centers. In 1932, Choral Singing gained considerable space in educational policies because of Villa-Lobos’ initiatives. Musical education became compulsory once more under Law number 11.769 of 2008.

item.texto: Decree number 1331 of 1854 signed by Emperor Dom Pedro II presented the first settings for musical education in schools under Brazilian law. It was restricted to the Federal District (Rio de Janeiro at the time), but reached other educational centers in Brazil.

Decree number 981 was published and it presented the first aspirations for musical education in schools of Republican Brazil. The national law in the following years didn´t bring any definition to musical education, but several towns incorporated teaching proposals and practice in the school context.

In the beginning of the 20th century choral singing was practiced by the students of the Escola Normal de São Paulo under the direction of João Gomes Júnior. From 1921, the São Paulo government was already in favor of having musical education in public schools and this movement reached greater relevance in the 30s with Villa-Lobos and the institutionalization of choral singing nationwide.

Villa-Lobos was appointed director of music and choral singing of the General Department of Municipal Public Education of the Federal District in Rio de Janeiro. The first choir presentations had the participation of teachers and, afterwards, of students from public schools.
Villa-Lobos’ masterpiece, “Guia Prático”, was first edited containing 138 versions of popular children and folk songs and it was the basis of the repertoire for choral singing activities in schools.
The activities and courses of the Superintendence of Musical and Artistic Education (SEMA) undertaken by Villa-Lobos in 1932 led to the creation of the National Choral Singing Music Academy in 1942.

Law 5682/71 brought the definition of “Artistic Education” as a compulsory subject in primary and secondary education. It was consolidated as the multi-faceted art subject weakening the presence of musical education as a curricular component in schools. In 1977, the CFE 540 report referenced the types of music education limiting them to musical theory and choral singing.
Following a national movement mediated by musical educators and musicians as well as by members of society, law number 11769 was approved and musical education became mandatory in public schools.

descricao: Joaquim Callado founds the first group of "chorões" (musicians that play the Choro genre), named "Choro do Callado". The group was formed by a solo instrument (his flute), two guitars and a cavaquinho, and there was another string instruments for the harmonic base.

item.texto: Oito Batutas’ first appearance in Rio de Janeiro; one of the most important popular music bands of the time, formed by Pixinguinha, Donga and João Pernambuco, amongst others.

Villa-Lobos composes Choro No. 1, the first in a series of pieces in which the composer places Choro in the context of classical music. The series was made up of 14 Choros written between 1920 and 1929 for different formations.

The Benedito Lacerda Regional Ensemble is created. At the time, such regional ensembles were formed by one or more solo instruments (flute, cavaquinho, mandolin, clarinet, etc.), string instruments (guitar, 7 string guitar, etc.) and percussion (generally the tambourine).

The architect Alfredo Britto hosts a Choro circle in his house in the carioca district of Santa Teresa, which went on to become a tradition in the city’s calendar, always falling on the first Saturday of each year. Amongst the participants there was Paulinho da Viola, Raphael Rabello, the Spaniard, Paco de Lucia and the Cuban, Paquito de Rivera, as well as others.

The Portable Choro School was created in order to teach music through the language of Choro, and starts its activities in Sala Funarte Sidney Miller, in the centre of Rio. The classes changed venue three times: firstly, to the UFRJ Music School in Lapa, next to the Casa da Glória and finally, to Uni-Rio at Urca.

The House of Choro was inaugurated in Carioca Street, equipped with classrooms, a research centre, recording studio and an auditorium. The inauguration was celebrated with a festival in the Tiradentes Square on the 23rd and 24th April, bringing together stars such as Hamilton de Holanda, Yamandú Costa, Maurício Carrilho and the duo Zé da Velha & Silvério Pontes, among others.

descricao: Casa Edison, owned by Fred Figner, born Czech, start phonographic recordings in Rio de Janeiro. Installed at Rua do Ouvidor, the establishment opens the first recording studio in the country. Almost 3000 recordings were made between 1902 and 1903.

item.texto: Fascinated by the inventions of Thomas Edison that made possible the recording and the reproduction of sounds by means of rotating cylinders, the young czech Fred Figner acquires one of these equipments and various recording rollers and embarks for Belém do Pará, in Brazil.

Figner arrives in Belém do Pará without speaking Portuguese. Even so he can show his novelty to the public, which pays to register and listen to their voices. The success takes him to other places in Brazil. In 1902, arriving in Rio de Janeiro, already understanding our language, Figner opens his first store, Casa Edison on Uruguaiana Street, importing and marketing the first phonographs.

The Odeon Talking Machine installs in Rio de Janeiro the first factory records of Latin America. Fred Figner, owner of Casa Edison, gets exclusive contract on the sale of records produced by the factory.

The record companies Victor and Brunswick were established in Rio de Janeiro, giving new impetus to the music industry in the country and opening market for instrumentalists, arrangers and conductors.

Released by Sinter the first LP in Brazil: "Carnival in long-playing", bringing together carnival compositions recorded by Oscarito, Heleninha Costa and Os Cariocas, among others, nobody with sucess. The vinyl record itself known as LP will only be a commercial success from the end of the decade, with the availability of disc players more accessible to consumers.

descricao: The first mention of frevo (a typical rhythm from Pernambuco) was pubished in the Recife's newspaper "Jornal Pequeno", an announcement that music "O frevo" would be presented at club Empalhadores do Feitosa. This rhythm is derived from the march, maxixe and capoeira. The word "frevo" is related to the verb boil (in Portuguese, "ferver") and means agitation and effervescence.

item.texto: Frevo das Vassourinhas, also known as Vassourinhas, composed by Mathias da Rosa is released and considered Recife's Carnival theme. Severino Araújo accompanied by the Tabajara Orchestra only recorded the piece in 1949.
First recording of the piece Frevo Pernambucano, composed by Luperce Miranda and Oswaldo Santiago and performed by Francisco Alves.
The marchinha O teu cabelo não nega mulata composed this same year is, in fact, an adaptation made by Lamartine Babo of the Frevo Mulata, composed by Valença Brothers from Pernambuco.
The Frevo Evocação number 1 composed by Nelson Ferreira and recorded by Batutas de São José group break into Rio's carnival along with marchinhas and samba.
Frevo is included at the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO.

descricao: The recording of “Pelo Telefone”, by Donga, marks the birth of the genre “samba’, even if some people claim that there were previous examples.

item.texto: Until the recording of Pelo Telefone, there were in Brazil many forms of samba originating from African rhythms. As an urban musical expression, it is understood that samba emerged between the late nineteenth and early twentieth century in Rio de Janeiro, when that genre came into contact with polka and maxixe, being born a new genre of singular character.

Considered the oldest samba school in Rio, G.R.E.S.
