Estácio de Sá was born in the neighborhood of the same name, near Onze Square, stronghold of samba, batucada and candomblé, a stage of classic samba's world characters such as Tia Ciata, Donga and Sinhô. The initial nickname "Deixa Falar" was suggested by his founder, Ismael Silva.

Composers of Estácio de Sá neighborhood from Rio de Janeiro (especially Ismael Silva, Newton Bastos and Alcebíades Barcelos) reformulate the samba, freeing it from the cultural heritage of the maxixe and giving it its own "physiognomy", a standard that makes it the most important genre of the popular Brazilian Music.

Between the end of the 1920s and the mid-1940s, urban samba in Rio ceased to be considered as a local expression to be raised, with the help of the state, to a status of national symbol. The different ramifications, such as samba de carnaval, samba-exaltação and samba-canção, spread by the radio waves in the voice of Francisco Alves and Carmem Miranda, among others.

Heitor dos Prazeres launches the samba “Eu choro” and the term "breque" (from the English "break"). It was the beginning of the samba-de-breque, characterized by the syncopated rhythm and with abrupt stops (called breques), so that the singer could make some intervention, like comments or humorous phrases, giving grace and jokes to the narrative.

At the end of the 30's comes up a style of samba of "legalistic" character, later known like samba-exaltation appears. This branch of samba was characterized by compositions that exalted the work or the country, such as Aquarela do Brasil, recorded in 1939 by Francisco Alves and that became the first Brazilian international music success.

Rises “Movimento de Revitalização do Samba de Raiz” (a movement to promote a revival of traditional samba), at the same time as the appearance of the Zicartola bar, the samba shows at the Teatro de Arena and musicals like Rosa de Ouro, which revealed Araci Cortes and Clementina de Jesus.

1970: The 70's marks a period of revaluation of samba after comes up of bossa nova. New artists are projected commercially as Alcione, Beth Carvalho and Clara Nunes, as well as Bezerra da Silva, Martinho da Vila and Paulinho da Viola. The traditional sambistas, like Candeia, Cartola and Nelson Cavaquinho, consecrate themselves with the recording of their works.

Inaugurated at Marquês de Sapucaí Avenue, in the center of Rio de Janeiro, with an Oscar Niemeyer project, the Sambódromo will celebrate the parade of samba schools as one of the most important carnival events in the world.

descricao: The first radio broadcast transmission in Brazil take part of the centenary Independence Day celebrations, with a speech of the President Epitácio Pessoa.

item.texto: On April 20 is inaugurated the first radio station in Brazil, by Edgard Roquette-Pinto and Henrique Morize, using borrowed equipment by the government in Praia Vermelha, Rio de Janeiro. From October the same year, the station's programming now includes literary conferences, vocal and instrumental music.
One of the earliest radio stations to be broadcast throughout the Brazilian territory, The Nacional Radio has been consolidated since its foundation as one of the most important in the country.

On September 7 Roquette-Pinto, unable to maintain and modernize the equipment of Society Radio, donates the radio station to the then Ministry of Education and Health. The station is now called Radio Ministry of Education.

The program “Reporter Esso” will on air on August 28, the same day in which Brazil united with allied forces to fight the German army in the Second World War. It was characterized by being the first with news written especially for the radio, was narrated by the speakers Celso Guimarães, Romeu Fernandes, Saint-Clair Lopes, Aurélio de Andrade and Jorge Curi.

The "A Million Melodies" program premieres sponsored by Coca-Cola, this year launching the soda in Brazil. The Brazilian Orchestra was created, with direction of Radamés Gnatalli, presenting 7 songs of success: two current Brazilian, two old and three foreign songs.

The singer Marlene wins the election of radio’s queen, promoted by Brazilian Radio Association, contrary to predictions that pointed to the favoritism of Emilinha Borba. Voting, through coupons purchased by voters, was defined when the Antarctica Paulista Company supported Marlene and took advantage of the victory to divulge his new soda: the Guaraná Caçula.

It is created by the Radio Ministry of Education the program “Music and Musicians of Brazil”. Composers, conductors and interpreters dedicated to Brazilian concert music are interviewed. It is in the air until today, being transmitted by MEC FM Radio.

descricao: The producer Cornélio Pires records, for the first time, 6 discs (from a 52 discs series) with country music and little jokes. Due to great receptivity of people, from 7th disc the Columbia company takes the production. Born in Brazil the new and lucrative segment of the phonographic industry, the country music.

item.texto: The “Turma do Cornélio Pires” formed by viola (country guitar) players and singers from Piracicaba, an inland city from São Paulo state, reaches a huge market success and attracts the eyes from recording label Victor who decides to invest in this new segment and sends equipment to record the duo “Lourenço e Olegário”.

Duo “Lourenço e Olegário” transfer to the record label Parlophom assuming the alias “Mandy e Sorocabinha”. The success of their first recordings of the country music was huge within the inland São Paulo state.

The country ("sertaneja") music reaches its high from the 1940’s and 1950’s with a history of success of the duos at the record labels and radio. At this moment, the viola still is the companion instrument in use.

After the II World War, new genres add up to the traditional sertaneja music, such as the Paraguayan guarânia. Romantic themes slowly replace the lyrics originally connected to the country lifestyle. At this time the “Irmãs Galvão” and “Cascatinha e Inhana” duos begin to rise.
Renato Teixeira, an important name from sertaneja and country music, composer of great successes such as Romaria and Frete, records his first album “Maranhão e Ricardo Teixeira”.
Since the end of 1960’s the electric guitar was already present at the sertaneja music and in this year Sérgio Reis begins its career at the genre after participating the "Jovem Guarda" movement.
The Parada Dura Trio active since 1975 hit the top charts with the song Fuscão Preto and four years later releases another hit song As andorinhas.
Chitãozinho e Xororó, another duo from São Paulo inland, record their first hit, the song Fio de Cabelo.
The duo “Leandro e Leonardo” record Entre tapas e beijos for Continental label reaching enormous national success.

A well-established genre at the recording industry from the 1990’s, the sertaneja music transforms itself massively adding electronic instruments and urban themes. Along with the duos, solo singers appears and the “sertanejo universitário” is born.

descricao: Villa-Lobos is nominated to hold the position of Director of Music and Orpheonic Singing at the Municipal Public Education Department, in Rio de Janeiro. The teachers debuted the series of presentations, and in sequence the public school students.

item.texto: At the beginning of the XX century, orpheonic singing was practiced by the normalists of the Normal School of São Paulo, under direction of João Gomes Júnior. From 1921 onwards, the São Paulo government was already in favor of teaching music in public schools, a movement that would reach greater prominence in the 1930s with Villa-Lobos and the institutionalization of orpheonic singing.

The "Guia Prático" is edited for the first time, Villa-Lobos masterpiece containing 138 versions of popular and folkloric children's songs, base of the repertoire for the activities of the orpheonic singing in the schools.

The success of the activities and courses of the Superintendency of Musical and Artistic Education (SEMA), coordinated by Villa-Lobos since 1932, lead to the formation of the National Conservatory of Orpheonic Singing in 1942.

descricao: Created in 1938 by H. J. Koellreutter, the first achievements were realized in 1939 until the 1940's, generating intense cultural activity such as concertos, conferences and newsletters. In the first phase, names like Claudio Santoro and Guerra-Peixe, among others, show the atonality and dodecaphony to Brazil. The 1944 and 1946 Manifestos open the 2nd and 3rd phases of the movement.

item.texto: Claudio Santoro begins his studies with Koellreutter, being his first student to actively engage in the Movement. A little later, Guerra-Peixe and Edino Krieger (students of the German master as well) join the Movement.

The first radio transmission of the series of weekly programs called “Música Viva” takes place at the Radio of the Ministry of Education and Health in Rio de Janeiro. The premiere exclusively comprised of contemporary Brazilian works.

Launch of the Manifest of 1946 – Declaration of Principles. The document opens a new phase of the Movement with the promotion of the avant-garde music, breaking definitively away from the nationalist line.

In May 19th the radio series “Música Viva” broadcasts a program called “Música para crianças” (Music for children). The program contained works of Prokofieff, Guerra-Peixe, and Camargo Guarnieri, hence demonstrating the educational background of the Movement.
Creation of the Pró-Arte’s International Vacation Courses, in Teresópolis, whose aim is to promote and debate the contemporary music.
As a belated result of the Movement, the series of International Music Seminars of the Federal University of Bahia – UFBA begins, in Salvador.

nome: Baião emerges in Brazil and around the world
descricao: Luiz Gonzaga, who had begun his career recording choro and valses, records for the first time RCA Victor one baião: Meu pé de Serra (in partnership with Humberto Teixeira). From there the baião becomes national success and the gender recordings start to run the world.

item.texto: Câmara Cascudo reports that the baião reaches success from that year, with Luis Gonzaga, although before that there were already popular demonstrations of this rhythm. Its original execution was with the accordion, but with the popularization began to use orchestration.
According to the magazine Radar, the newspapers of that time recorded that the baião has become a national success.
The new succesful rhythm begins to be recorded by several artists, among them are Marlene, Emilinha Borba, Ivon Curi, Carmem Miranda and Jamelão.

After a brief period of forgetfulness, during the previous decade, from the 70's the baião resurfaced in the scene of popular music with Dominguinhos and João do Vale, among others. The rhythm influenced the tropicalism of Gilberto Gil and also the rock of another composer from Bahia, Raul Seixas.

nome: The rock 'n' roll arrives in Brazil
descricao: Influenced by rock precursors in the United States, such as Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, among others, the genre began to be recorded in Brazil, first Portuguese versions to songs like Rock around the clock, by Nora Ney.

item.texto: The first edition of the Hollywood Rock Festival took place in the Botafogo stadium in Rio de Janeiro, with participants being big names in the national rock scene: Rita Lee, Erasmo Carlos, Cely Campelo, Raul Seixas and bands such as O Terço, Mutantes and Vímana (Lulu Santos, Ritchie and Lobão). The event was produced by the journalist Nelson Motta.

The project “Rock Voador” was a partnership between the Circo Voador in Rio de Janeiro and Fluminense Radio, which contributed to forming an audience base for the music genre in the country. Of the 258 bands that performed at the Circo, the most notable were: Barão Vermelho, Titãs, Legião Urbana, Biquini Cavadão, Paralamas do Sucesso, Ultraje a Rigor, Engenheiros do Hawaii and RPM.

The biggest rock festival carried out in Latin America, Rock in Rio, thought up by the entrepreneur Roberto Medina, brought big names in international pop music to Rio de Janeiro for the first time. It was held in Jacarpaguá, in an area since known as the City of Rock, and brought together around 1 million people.

Rock in Rio celebrates its 32nd anniversary. The various editions of the festival, which has now become a brand, have been hosted in Brazil as well as abroad, bringing together thousands of people to each edition, and relying upon the participation of renowned artists in the world rock scene.

descricao: Two phonographic releases mark the beginning of bossa nova: LP "Canção do Amor Demais", with music by Tom Jobim and Vinicius de Morais, interpreted by Elizeth Cardoso and "Chega de Saudade", 78 rpm record released by João Gilberto.

item.texto: The latent spirit of bossa nova can already be understood in the song Se todos fossem iguais a você, written for the play ‘Orfeu da Conceiçao ‘. This song was a result of the first partnership between Tom Jobim and Vinícius de Moraes.

In this year, the first public appearance of the term "bossa nova" occurs in a concert by singer Sylvia Telles, conducted by the Hebrew University Group in its headquarters in Rio de Janeiro. At the entrance of the show was a blackboard with the following text: "Today, Sylvinha Telles and a bossa nova group".

Many bossa nova critics consider the launching of the single of João Gilberto in 1958, with the songs Chega de saudade (by Tom Jobim and Vinícius de Moraes) and Bim Bom (by Gilberto himself) the instigation of the musical style. But it was from the release of his LP "Chega de saudade" the following year, that bossa nova became a reality in the music scene.

The singer Maysa records Eu sei que vou te amar, by Tom Jobim and Vinícius de Moraes. Maintaining the original rhythm and arrangement, through the deep voice of the singer, the iconic song of its genre gained dramatic flair.
Tom Jobim composes Corcovado, another enormous bossa nova success. Later, Gene Lees writes a version of the lyrics in English.

The great success Samba de uma nota só, a composition by Tom Jobim with lyrics by Newton Mendonça, is recorded by João Gilberto in the LP "O amor, o sorriso e a flor". Jobim translated the verses into English and the song achieved enormous international success, appearing in the repertoire of the LP "Jazz Samba" (Jobim, Byrd, Getz) in 1962 and winning the Grammy that year.

Through a successful partnership, bossa nova icons Roberto Menescal and Ronaldo Boscoli compose "O barquinho". Artists like Nara Leão, Maysa, Elis Regina and João Gilberto would later perform their own renditions of the song.

A show with Brazilian artists at Carnegie Hall in New York would put bossa nova on the international stage. João Gilberto, Antonio Carlos Jobim, Carlos Lyra and Luís Bonfá, among others, participated in the event.

In July the first recording of the samba "Garota de Ipanema" (by Tom Jobim and Vinicius de Moraes) in the voice of Pery Ribeiro, in a single in Odeon is released. It is the most well-known Brazilian song in the world after "Aquarela do Brasil" (by Ary Barroso), with more than 160 recordings by singers like Frank Sinatra and Ella Fitzgerald.

A group of artists inspired by a nationalist vision cause ruptures in the bossa nova movement, proposing less influence from American jazz, and instead the re-encounter with samba composers of favela. In the group were Marcos Valle, Edu Lobo, Carlos Lyra and Nara Leão, among others. The following year, Vinícius de Moraes and Baden Powell released the unforgettable LP "The afro-sambas".

The bossa nova gives space and little by little it is inserted in the category of MPB - Popular Brazilian Music. The previous year, one of its main advocates, Vinícius de Moraes, composes "Arrastão" in collaboration with Edu Lobo. The song would later be defended and interpreted by Elis Regina at the Brazilian Popular Music Festival, promoted by TV Excelsior in 1965, held in Guarujá.

nome: Clube da Esquina movement is born
descricao: The meetings of young musicians on the corner of Divinopolis and Paraisopolis streets, in Belo Horizonte, to talk about their compositions, originated the musical movement known as Clube da Esquina. Among them were Milton Nascimento, Lô Borges, Toninho Horta, Beto Guedes, Marcio Borges,Túlio Mourão, Fernando Brant, Ronaldo Bastos and Wagner Tiso.

item.texto: Milton Nascimento arrives in Belo Horizonte to work and study. Already knowing Wagner Tirso, with whom he played, he meets the Borges brothers (Marilton, Márcio and Lô). The group begins to get together along with other musicians who start arriving, resulting in the musical movement called Clube da Esquina (Corner Club), with influences from bossa-nova, jazz, rock and classical music.

New musicians such as Flávio Venturini, Vermelho, Toninho Horta and Beto Guedes join the movement, bringing musical influences from the Beatles and The Platters. They are joined also by lyricists Fernando Brant and Ronaldo Bastos.

The LP "Clube da Esquina" is released by EMI records. The songs bring a rich mix of styles from bossa-nova, jazz, psychedelic rock and rhythms from the state of Minas Gerais, allied with poetic lyrics. They were the first in MPB (Popular Brazilian Music) to promote a musical integration between Brasil and Latin America, World Music pioneers.
The LP "Clube da Esquina II" is released, organized by Milton Nascimento and produced by Ronaldo Bastos.

nome: Show Opinião takes place in Rio de Janeiro
descricao: Starring Nara Leao, Ze Keti and João do Valle, directed by Augusto Boal, the show Opinião presented at the Arena Theater of Rio de Janeiro was an important milestone. It had a critical content to Brazilian social problems, consolidating the so-called Brazilian protest music.

The 2nd Brazilian Popular Music Festival is held in September and October  at TV Record, in Sao Paulo. Two songs shared first place: A banda by Chico Buarque and Disparada by Théo de Barros and Geraldo Vandré.

item.texto: That year TV showed several broadcasting festivals: among them the 2nd TV Excelsior Festival  (winner song was Porta-estandarte by Geraldo Vandré and Fernando Lona, with Tuca in the vocals), and the 1st International Festival of Music (FIC) streamed on TV Rio, winner song was Saveiros by Dori Caymmi and Nelson Motta, interpreted by Nana Caymmi.

TV Record premieres the 2nd Festival of Brazilian Popular Music. First prize is awarded in split between A banda, march by Chico Buarque interpreted by himself in a duet with Nara Leão; and Disparada, by Geraldo Vandré and Theo de Barros in the voice of Jair Rodrigues.

The 3rd Festival of Brazilian Popular Music awards Ponteio (Edu Lobo and Capinan). Other spotlights were Roda-viva by Chico Buarque and Alegria, alegria by Caetano Veloso. At that occasion, Sérgio Ricardo broke his guitar and throw it over the public who booed his interpretation of Beto bom de bola.

In September, song Sabiá by Tom Jobim and Chico Buarque wins the 3rd FIC interpreted by Cynara and Cybele; in second place the involving Para não dizer que não falei das flores composed and sang by Geraldo Vandré. Public does not forgive alleged jury’s alienation and boos resound all around Maracanãzinho.

At the end of the Biennial of Samba, Baden Powell’s Lapinha wins, bringing as lyricist the newbie Paulo César Pinheiro. Among the finalists are Bom tempo by Chico Buarque, Tive sim by Cartola and Coisas do mundo, minha nega by Paulinho da Viola.

In December, the 5th Brazilian Popular Music Festival, the last festival of TV Record production, awards the victory for Sinal fechado, song by Paulinho da Viola (interpreted by the same) that also conquers a prize of better arrangement. While better lyrics prize is given to Luiz Gonzaga Jr. for his samba called Moleque.

Some songs presented on the 7th FIC: Papagaio do futuro by Alceu Valença, a march-ranch Eu quero é botar meu bloco na rua by Sérgio Sampaio and Fio Maravilha by Jorge Ben, this last was the contest winner together with Diálogo by Paulo César Pinheiro and Baden Powell.

The final of the 7th and last edition of International Festival of Music takes place, but derives more repercussion from jury panel’s reaction to Federal Censorship (when a jury was trying to read a manifest, and one of them was brutally battered by a guard of TV Globo, network broadcasting the competition) than by its musical aspect.

Maracanãzinho hosts the final of MPB 80 Festival, where wins Agonia by Mongol, interpreted by Oswaldo Montenegro. In second place was Foi Deus quem fez você by Luis Ramalho with Amelinha singing. Highlights were Clareana by Joyce and Reunião de bacana by Ari do Cavaco and Bebeto São João.

Maracanãzinho hosts the final of the Festival of Festivals – great event promoted by Rede Globo, which awards the victory to Escrito nas estrelas by Arnaldo Black and Carlos Rennó, interpreted by Tetê Espíndola.

descricao: As told by the journalist Nelson Motta: "(...) a filmmakers, journalists, musicians and intellectuals' group decided founded a movement able to be a worldwide success: the Tropicalism.” Artists such as Caetano Veloso, Gilberto Gil, Tom Zé and Os Mutantes played a fundamental hole in the movement that transformed popular music, poetry and other arts.

item.texto: It's released by Philips the LP “Tropicália ou Panis et circencis”, which gathered artists from the movement such as Gilberto Gil, Caetano Veloso, Os Mutantes, Tom Zé, Nara Leão, Gal Costa, between others, and arrangements of Rogério Duprat. Among the songs are Panis et circensis (by Caetano and Gil) and Baby (by Caetano).

Due to the participation on the tropicalist movement, whose characteristics of protesting against the military coup in 1964 and subsequent authoritarian government can be noted in the song É Proibido Proibir  ("It’s forbidden to forbid"), for example, in 1969 Caetano and Gil were arrested and then forced to exile in London, staying there until 1972.

Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil release by Polygram the album “Tropicália 2”, to celebrate the 25 years of the movement. The repertoire contains the successes Haiti (by Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil) and Desde que o samba é samba (by Caetano Veloso).
Releasing of a documentary “Tropicália”, directed by Marcelo Machado and produced by Fernando Meirelles.

descricao: Brazilian funk emerges in 1970's at the suburbs and has origins in soul music from USA. The genre quickly achieved success with his characteristic syncopated beat and lyrics expressing the dificult daily lives of favelas.

item.texto: Nelson Triunfo and the group Funk & Cia contribute for hip hop culture's dissemination in Brazil showing the breakdance in São Paulo streets.
Release of the albuns “Hip Hop Cultura de Rua” and “Consciência Black, Vol. I”, with the debut of Racionais MC’s, Thaíde and DJ Hum, among others.

The album collection “Funk Brasil” is released, with songs like Melô do bêbado (by DJ Marlboro and MC Batata),  Melô do arrastão (by Abdula, Nirto and DJ Marlboro), Melô da mulher feia (a version by Abdula, Nirto and DJ Marlboro for the composition by Barry and Greenwich) and Rap das aranhas (by Raul Seixas and Cláudio Roberto).
The authorities of Rio de Janeiro create a commission to investigate the link between funk and drugs trafficking. So, funk dances are prohibited around the city and take place only in clubs.
The Rio de Janeiro State law number 3410, published in May 29th this year, sets strict rules for the conduct of funk dances, including the mandatory presence of police in the events.

The funk Bonde da Juju, composed and interpreted by Backdi and MC Bio-G3, opens a new dimension to funk named "funk ostentação". Created in São Paulo and Santos, the "funk ostentação" usually has lyrics centered in money's power.
This year is pubished the Decree-law number 5.543 recognizing funk as a cultural movement in Rio de Janeiro State.
It happens a big event in favor of funk in Rio de Janeiro, the Rio Parada Funk, with many performances and about a hundred thousand people in the streets.

The Duelo de MC's was created in 2007 and in 2012 becomes a national event, being consider a cultural manifestation in Brazil. In August, 26th this year, the artists MCs Gênio, Douglas Din, Mirapotira, Set, Buddy Poke, Biro Biro, Tagarela and FBC competed for the title of best improvisational MC.

descricao: As a result of counterculture movement in Pernambuco, in 1970's born the Udigrudi Movement, in Recife. It was a period of great musical criativity with the band Ave Sangria and artists such as Alceu Valença, Flaviola and the Bando do Sol, Lula Côrtes, Marconi Notaro and Lailson, among others. From Paraíba, Zé Ramalho also took part of the movement.

item.texto: The Santa Isabel Theater holds the event I Parto de Música Livre do Nordeste, with performances by Marco Polo and Tamarineira Village, Luís Gonzaga, Carmélia Alves and a polemical performance by Flaviola, with a tone of challenge to social standards, which are characteristics of the artistic manifestations of the Udigrudi movement.
Laílson and Lula Côrtes, members of the Pernambuco's Udigrudi movement, produce and release their LP “Satwa” under the trademark Abakadabra.
Fred Zero Quatro, founder of the band Mundo Livre S/A, publishes the manifesto “Caranguejos com cérebro”, drawing attention to the Manguebeat counterculture movement that was taking place in Recife.

Born in Recife, the Manguebeat movement has two important  releases this year: the album “Da Lama ao Caos”, by Chico Science & Nação Zumbi, under the trademarks Chaos/ Sony Music, and “Samba Esquema Noise” which comes out on Banguela Records.

In an interview with journalist Cristiano Barros, Zé da Flauta answers the question “Can someone define Udigrudi?”: “It's just a terminology. In that case, in the 70's, it did not characterize itself as a musical movement. It was only a moment of excitement, disturbance and artistic restlessness. It was not an idea with manifest and an objective, as was the Manguebeat during the 90's.”

descricao: The 1st Brazilian Contemporary Music Biennial came from the 1st and 2nd Guanabara Music Festivals, created by Edino Krieger in 1969 and 1970. Supported by Myrian Dauelsberg, from Cecília Meireles Hall in Rio de Janeiro, it held in 1975 the 1st Biennial. The first three editions were organized by Cecilia Meirelles Hall group and from the fourth were directed by Funarte.

item.texto: On 8 October, in the Cecilia Meireles Hall, the First Biennial began with the presentation of Estruturas Primitivas, by Ricardo Tacuchian. The event would take place from 8 to 12 October, with the participation of 35 composers.
The II Biennial will be held between 15 and 23 October in Rio de Janeiro, with the execution and debut of several works by renowned authors, among them Esther Scliar and Edino Krieger.

The III Biennial takes place from 12 to 19 October.  On October 20th, the newspaper Jornal do Brasil in its cultural supplement Caderno B announces the event and highlights the participation of an expressive group of authors and interpreters.
The IV Biennial, held between 23 and 30 October, opens space for various activities such as lectures, discussions and debates.

The V Biennial takes place between 4 - 12 November, coordinated by the composer Ricardo Tacuchian, emphasizing the plurality of styles - from the neoclassicism of Camargo Guarnieri to the electroacoustic of Vânia Dantas Leite.

The VI Biennial, held from 8 to 17 November, brought together 67 composers between established masters and novices. Among the works, Marlos Nobre’s O Canto multiplicado; Miniópera by Henrique de Curitiba and Dramatic Polimaniquexixe, by Jorge Antunes.

The VII Biennial had the participation of 79 composers, taking place from 5 - 14 November. Ronaldo Miranda was the coordinator of the event and, among others, Rodrigo Cicchelli and the vocal ensemble Garganta Profunda premiered.
From 22 to 30 of November, the VIII Biennial takes place. Works such as the Symphony n.14, by Claudio Santoro, were performed at the event.
The IX Biennial would be held from October 18th to 27th. In that year, the Biennial incorporated a new space, the Leopoldo Miguez Hall at the School of Music of UFRJ.
The tenth edition of the Biennial takes place from 15 and 23 October, with the participation of 86 composers and tributes to Mário de Andrade, Ascendino Nogueira, Camargo Guarnieri and Breno Blauth.

The XI Biennial takes place from 23 to 30 November. At the opening there was the prerelease of film "Camargo Guarnieri encantamento" by José Sette and the exhibition of "Alberto Nepomuceno" by Humberto Mauro. Almeida Prado, together with Mário Tavares, Hans-Joachim Koellreutter, Eudóxia de Barros and Cleofe Person de Mattos were given the National Music Prize at the time.
The XII Biennial takes place between 25 October and 4 November, crowding the Municipal Theater of Rio de Janeiro in its opening concert.
At the XIII Biennial, held between 20 and 29 October of this year, it was sought to rescue the trajectory of Brazilian musical nationalism through the ages.

The XIV Biennial, which took place between 22 and 31 October, was contended by more than 160 composers, confirming the success of the event. Between opera adaptation, concerts and CDs, the event revealed the new Brazilian musical production.

In the XV Biennial that happened between 9 and 16 November, paying great tribute to composer Edino Krieger. This edition was limited to chamber and instrumental music. Also worthy of mention are the music reading course in Braille and the film and video exhibition about Brazilian music at the Gustavo Capanema Palace.
The 30th anniversary of the Biennial was celebrated this year between 4 and 13 November. The XVI edition counted with significant participation of young composers.
The XVII Biennial happens between 21 and 30 October.

The XVIII Biennial was attended by 110 composers, several interpreters and the American musician Tom Moore. The world premiere of Edino Krieger's Pequeno Concerto for Violin and Strings was a highlight.
The XIX Biennial honored the composer Almeida Prado, deceased the previous year, and was coordinated by Flávio Silva.
The XX Biennial happens with the participation of several composers, consolidating even more the event in the Brazilian cultural scene.
At the XXI Biennial, which took place between 10 and 19 October, paying great tribute to Mário de Andrade and Hans-Joachim Koellreutter.

The XXII Biennial takes place between October 23 and 29, with the presentation of 61 new pieces. The honorees of this edition were the composers Sérgio Roberto de Oliveira (1970-2017) and Olivier Toni (1926-2017), besides the ambassador, historian and musicologist Vasco Mariz (1921-2017).

descricao: One of the most important cultural movements ocurred between 1979 and 1985 in São Paulo. The label "Vanguarda Paulistana" was created by musical critics and journalists due to the vanguard aspects, the manifestations that took place mainly in the Lira Paulistana Theater. Among the new talents were Arrigo Barnabé, Itamar Assumpção, Tetê and Alzira Espíndola and Cida Moreira.

item.texto: The Lira Paulistana Theater opens in October in the Pinheiros neighborhood of São Paulo. There was the first launching platform of the Vanguard Paulistana, where Arrigo Barnabé and Itamar Assumpção, pillars of the movement, along with Tetê Espíndola, meet with Eliete Negreiros, Ná Ozzetti and groups like Premeditando o Breque and Língua de Trapo, among others.

The movement of underground artists from São Paulo marks the consolidation of the so-called "independent disc" in Brazil. In 1980, Arrigo Barnabé started production and released his first album "Clara Crocodilo". From then on, independent productions became a trademark of so-called alternative artists.

Although it has won praise among the critics, the movement has never reached public success. Most artists follow a solo career. In 1985, Tetê Espíndola wins the Festival of Festivals with the song Escrito nas estrelas.

nome: The punk movement arrives in Brazil
descricao: The festival “O começo do fim do mundo” is realized in november, in São Paulo. It was considered a landmark of punk rock in Brazil, with performances of Cólera and Inocentes bands, among others. The same year, both bands took part of the first punk rock album in Brazil, “Grito Suburbano”, by Punk Rock Records.The band Olho Seco also participated in this album.

item.texto: Release of the punk rock album "Grito Suburbano", created by three of the main bands of the genre: Inocentes, Olho Seco e Cólera. The album brings together a compilation with 4 tracks of each band and represented a landmark for the time.

The festival "O começo do fim do mundo" takes place at SESC Pompéia, in São Paulo. It was one of the biggest punk rock events in Brazil, gathering bands like Basement Rats, Cholera, Dry Eye, Ulster, Suburban, M19 and Deserters, among others.

The band Sepultura, from Minas Gerais, revolutionizes their techniques with the entrance of Andreas Kisser and the release of the CD "Schizophrenia", occupying definitively place in the international hit parades.
The band Sepultura releases the album "Beneath the remains", by the Dutch record company Roadrunner Records. It was named by Terrorizer magazine as one of the 20 best thrash metal albums of all time.

nome: Axé Music and other northeastern rhythms
descricao: The term “axé music” debuts in the Brazilian press by journalist Hagamenon Brito, initially in a pejorative way. Nevertheless, the new genre achieves huge success and it is followed by other rhythms such as Lambada and Arrocha.

item.texto: The Bahian singer and composer Luiz Caldas releases his LP "Magia" which includes the big hit Fricote within its repertoire (in collaboration with Paulinho Camafeu), considered to mark the beginning of Axé music.
The Bahian group Olodum releases its first album, "Egito Madagascar"; it included the big hits Madagascar Olodum (by Rey Zulu) and Faraó (by Luciano Gomes).

Marks the beginnings of the Lambada rhythm with the release of Lambada - Chorando se foi, (José Ari and Márcia Ferreira’s version for the composition by Ulisses Hermosa and Gonzalo Hermosa) and Dançando Lambada (Zé Maria) by the French-Brazilian group Kaoma.

The Bahian band Banda Mel releases the song Baianidade nagô (composed by Evany). Together with Prefixo de verão, composed by Beto Silva and released in 1990, these two songs were the breakthrough hits of their repertoire.

On the 23rd of June, the romantic singer Pablo (artistic name for Agenor Apolinário dos Santos Neto), who is an exponent of the Bahian music genre known as Arrocha, releases his sixth album, "É só dizer que sim". Pablo collaborated with Ivete Sangalo for the recording of the major hit Vingança do amor (Magno Santana, Filipe Benteque and Tierry Coringa).

descricao: The law 11.769 is sanctioned this year and stablishes that musical education is now compulsory at the public schools. This was a great achievement for the area of Musical Education in Brazil.

item.texto: After the orpheonic chanting period in public schools (decades 40, 50 and early 60), the educational reform undertaken by the military regime (Law 5.692 / 71) gradually extinguished the teaching of music in grades 1 and 2. The teaching of art, under the name of Artistic Education, becomes compulsory curricular component, without specifying musical contents.
